text: It includes numerous influential high-quality journals in the world. It is also one of the most frequently used databases in previous bibliometric studies ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 16 </cite> ).

The database chosen to support this research has been Scopus [ <cite data-doi="10.1186/1742-5581-3-1"> 70 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9"> 71 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 72 </cite> ]. Key reasons behind the choice include easy accessibility, extensive repository of publications, and the ability to download a full record in RIS or CSV format for analysis with software tools.

Scopus has one of the largest abstracts and citation databases for research literature. Researchers consider it a high-quality, versatile, and respected research database ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 19 </cite> ).

Scopus was chosen over Web of Science (WoS) <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[15]</cite> due to its broader journal coverage and participation of researchers from developing countries. The SCImago journal ranking [6] and the Scopus [49] source list were chosen as baseline lists for collecting the JMSs and additional information.

We selected this digital library because it contains publications from major journals and conference proceedings, and it is one of the largest curated bibliographic abstract and citation databases of research literature ( <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00019"> 17 </cite> ). Moreover, recent bibliographic research indicated it as the most comprehensive and user-friendly database ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9"> 18 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 19 </cite> ).

In the humanities, the three databases perform poorly in all subfields, and MA does not outperform Scopus and WoS. Thus, except for in psychology and economics/business, MA shows similar biases with regard to the social sciences and humanities as previous studies have identified in Scopus and WoS <cite data-doi="10.1093/reseval/rvw013">(Gumpenberger et al, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

Their operating is based on Bradford's law of scattering (elitist selection of sources) and a semi-controlled management of the bibliographic references. However, this does not make them immune to errors <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.07.003">(Franceschini, Maisano, and Mastrogiacomo 2016a;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2015.11.006">2016b)</cite> while introducing a series of notable biases towards certain disciplines such as Natural Sciences, Medicine Physics, and related, and serious limitations towards sources written in languages other than English <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>, which may lead to less accurate representation of the research capacity of certain universities.

In addition, Google Scholar was used as a supplementary source of literature. These databases cover most of the current literature and are, in turn, the most consulted by academic staff from various fields of knowledge <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[53]</cite>. After gathering all the retrieval records, removing duplicates, and screening out unqualified papers, the final sample consists of 55 articles (see Figure 1).

A limitation of this work is the scope of the databases searched. Thus, the inclusion of a specialized the Digital Government Reference Library (DGRL) database could broaden this research and strength analysis <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[40]</cite>.

We analyzed the coverage of the six major FOS fields and examined the social sciences, humanities, and natural sciences more closely. We focused on these three fields, as publication coverage is an issue in many subfields of the social sciences and humanities <cite data-doi="10.1093/reseval/rvw013">(Gumpenberger, Sorz, Wieland, & Gorraiz, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite> as well as in two subfields of the natural sciences, mathematics and computer/information sciences (Bosman, van Mourik, Rasch, Sieverts, & Verhoeff, 2006;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-010-0202-z">Larsen & von Ins, 2010)</cite>.

<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-016-2026-y">Harzing (2016)</cite> and <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-016-2185-x">Harzing and Alakangas (2017a)</cite> compared publication and citation coverage of MA with Scopus, Web of Science (WoS), and Google Scholar. <cite data-doi="10.1045/september2016-herrmannova">Herrmannova and Knoth (2016a)</cite> In evaluative bibliometrics, it is crucial to know how well a given database covers publications in order to decide whether it is valid for citation analysis <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. In the studies of <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-016-2026-y">Harzing (2016)</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-016-2185-x">Harzing and Alakangas (2017a)</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1045/september2016-herrmannova">and Herrmannova and Knoth (2016a)</cite>, the publication coverage of MA was addressed, but the results were inconclusive for two reasons.

Scopus database was selected as the source for academic articles' research due to the broad coverage, impact and quality of journals indexed in it, especially in the Social Sciences domain <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">(Harzing & Alakangas, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The research strategy included the use of the terms "knowledge-based development", "knowledge-based urban development", "knowledge economy" associated with "smart AND sustainable cities".

The present study uses the Scopus database due to several reasons. First, it was discovered that 84% of manuscripts that are indices in WoS were also included in Scopus [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 40 </cite> ]. Second, Scopus covers a wider number of journals than WoS, reducing in such a way the risk of omitting important manuscripts during the search.

Secondly, the choice of a database, Scopus, instead of another, such as the WoS database, may also be a constraint. However, Scopus was chosen because almost 84% of WoS articles can be found in Scopus [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 40 </cite> ]. Furthermore, fewer journals are indexed on WoS than on Scopus.

For instance, if Scopus covers relatively more journals than WoS in research fields in which it is relatively difficult to produce an accurate journal classification, then this could to some degree explain why in our analysis the classification system of Scopus appears to be less accurate than the WoS classification system. On the other hand, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul--Hus (2016)</cite> indicate that, even though Scopus has a broader coverage than WoS in all fields of science, the two databases have similar biases in their coverage of fields. In our analysis, we have focused mainly on relative rather than absolute statistics (e.g., the percentage of journals satisfying a criterion rather than the absolute number of journals satisfying a criterion).

Beyond this logical data structuring activity, there has also historically been the need for physical hardware, that effectively defines the computational capacity of the user. tion in the bibilometrics community over recent years <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2855-y">[5,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21372">18,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2854-z">23,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00031">28,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-011-0398-6">32,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.09.002">33,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">36,</cite><cite data-doi="10.48550/arxiv.1906.07011">44]</cite>. The emergence of new datasources has led to significant analytical efforts to understand the strengths and weaknesses of different approaches to collecting and indexing content <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03690-4">[34,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.outlook.2017.03.004">39,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.03.006">42,</cite><cite data-doi="10.48550/arxiv.2005.10732">46]</cite>.

Searches were conducted of ERIC (Educational Resources Information Center) and Scopus databases. The former was chosen as the oldest and largest database dedicated to education literature (Bell, 2015), while the latter was selected for its extensive coverage of social science journals (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). Searches were conducted using the following keyword search string, where + denotes a required term, and * returns all keywords containing the root: (+tweet OR +twitter) AND (education OR teach* OR learn* OR university OR college OR school).

Scopus consistently contains more records and citations than Dimensions as documents are aggregated by institutional association <cite data-doi="10.3389/frma.2020.593494">[33]</cite>. Although Dimensions and Scopus contain errors such as duplicate documents and citations, incomplete and incorrect bibliographic information <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[9]</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.03.006">[21]</cite>, these issues do not seem to be a problem for this study because the authors justify dismissing citation counts as unreliable on account of the bibliographic errors present in Dimensions and Scopus.

Also, the Web of Science was not part of the study. It can be taken as a work for the future <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[9]</cite>. Moreover, to make it more helpful to researchers for the importance of citations for the researchers' reputation, the interesting future work can be considered a motivation model for top-quality publications in <cite data-doi="10.17323/jle.2021.11522">[28]</cite>, [27] as a new motivational driver in existing literature models.

This correlation shows a positive relationship and a strong correlation between the two databases. This evidence corresponds to the results of other studies <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.09.002">[7]</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[9]</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03387-8">[13]</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03114-y">[15]</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00112">[29]</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2820-9">[34]</cite>- <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03690-4">[37]</cite>. These findings match the results found in <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.03.006">[21]</cite>.

This analysis created a portrait of Dimensions and Scopus journal coverage based on PSU's research productivity. According to the findings, Dimensions and Scopus' journal scope in the Humanities and Social Sciences is still very limited <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[9]</cite>. Further study should examine whether national publications that concentrate on local issues are well reflected in Dimensions and Scopus in the Humanities and Social Sciences.

University ranking is considered a measure of quality, effectiveness, and the universities' research performance <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[9]</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-008-2113-9">[38]</cite>. Further studies might need to compare citation data and the coverage of Dimensions and Scopus of a sample of scholars in different research fields.

This choice was based on Zhou et al <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ejor.2017.06.023">[41]</cite>, who claim that WoS is the main database of citations in the world due to the multidisciplinary coverage of high-impact journals in science and social sciences. Abrizah et al <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-012-0813-7">[42]</cite>, Chadegani et al <cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">[43]</cite>, and Mongeon and Paul-Hus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[44]</cite> also consider that WoS is one of the main databases used in bibliographic research and bibliometric analysis.

Both Scopus and WoS present advantages and disadvantages (Adriaanse and Rensleigh, 2013;<cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">Aghaei Chadegani et al, 2013)</cite>. As discussed at length in <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite>, even though the results from a search in one or the other databases will not generate the same results, both are valid for bibliometric studies. We note, however, that according to their analysis, social sciences are better represented in the Scopus® database.

The Scopus database has been chosen to support this research since it is easy to access, allows for the download of all the information available in different formats and is considered the largest repository of citations and abstracts <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">[63,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">64]</cite>. In addition, many researchers favor said database to perform bibliometric analyses, such as Janssen et al and Greenhalgh et al <cite data-doi="10.3390/su11205783">[65,</cite><cite data-doi="10.3390/su13031275">66]</cite>.

Bibliometric indicators are applied to evaluating bibliographic data, including the number of authors and articles, citations, institutions, and countries. Moreover, the documents used for the analysis were obtained from the largest database of multidisciplinary peer reviews of the Scopus literature <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). This database is widespread and often used to obtain quantitative analysis (Dur'an-S'anchez et al, 2019).

Moreover, we performed this analysis based on information that was obtained from Scopus. One of the strengths of this database is its comprehensive coverage on research from the social sciences <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. However, a significant amount of information may have been excluded through the occurrence of Bstray citations,^which is endemic to all bibliometric databases <cite data-doi="10.1108/14684520810914043">(Jacsó 2008)</cite>.

This relative immaturity, made us expand the literature search of this field. <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> recently noted that Scopus includes most of the journals that are indexed in the WoS, but also has a greater number of exclusive journals compared to the WoS. This was a compelling reason to select Scopus as our main source of bibliometric records.

To identify the most relevant literature on the topic, the databases used for this search were the main collection of the Web of Science and Scopus. In recent years, most systematic reviews have focused on these repositories because they archive the most prominent academic forums of any discipline <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[25,</cite><cite data-doi="10.3390/su11246964">26]</cite>. Given the objectives of the study, only the Social Sciences Citation Index (SSCI) of the Web of Science and the Social Science category of Scopus have been included, from 1956 to the present.

For example, Google Scholar and Scopus both have more coverage than the Web of Science data <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">(Harzing and Alakangas, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.31235/osf.io/42nkm">Mart ın-Mart ın et al, 2018)</cite>. But the data coverage of Web of science is more precise and valuable than Google Scholar and Scopus data <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">(Archambault et al, 2009;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing and Alakangas, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.31235/osf.io/42nkm">Mart ın-Mart ın et al, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Thus, bibliometric data has been collected from the Web of Science to provide more significant insights and development in e-tourism research.

Both Scopus and Web of Science are regarded among the most significant databases for social science field. In terms of journal coverage, Scopus is wider compared to Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite> but Web of Science produces greater number of articles with high impact factors <cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">(Chadegani et al, 2013)</cite>. The utilization of Google Scholar apart from these two databases in searching the relevant articles is because of the high accessibility rate of articles.

Scopus is acknowledged for its prestige and rigour as a large depository of peer-reviewed literature. Owing to its superior coverage of high-quality journals across different fields <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>, it is widely used to perform bibliometric analyses (e.g. Ahmi & Nasir, 2019;<cite data-doi="10.1108/cc-07-2017-0027">Kolle et al, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1186/s12992-018-0427-9">Sweileh, 2018)</cite>.

Dissension paths were explored by computing and comparing macro, meso, and micro structural network scores. Dataset and high-resolution figures are available in open access for replication and further use : http://bit.ly/2QyDJNP Data Bibliographic data was sourced from Scopus due to its journal coverage and LAC authors' involvement <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The query searched for articles published from 1998 to 2017 by at least one author affiliated with any LAC institution in SCImago's business, management, and accounting subject area (SCImago, 2020).

Scopus was chosen as the literature index platform for this analysis for a number of reasons. Compared with other indexing platforms such as Clarivate Web of Science, Scopus has better coverage of publications in the social sciences and health sciences, and also of journals covering multidisciplinary and emergent research approaches, such as the ones covered by the present study <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

One potential limitation was that the list is compiled by extracting data from Scopus database only, meaning that manuscripts not listed in Scopus were not included in the current report. Scopus in particular was chosen due to its broader coverage of biomedical literature relative to Web of Science, another well-known database that keeps track of citation data <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[31]</cite>. On the other hand, Google Scholar, for example, counts citations from non-academic sources such as websites, and hence was not selected by us for the current analysis.

In step three, we selected appropriate search databases to provide comprehensive coverage of the multiple research domains. Initially, to gain a broad overview, the Scopus database was searched based on its high-quality publications, user-friendliness and convenient sorting and ranking features <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. We then searched Google Scholar as a web-based academic search engine, which is typically used in literature reviews to screen the first 50-100 publications, and included doctoral and master theses <cite data-doi="10.1371/journal.pone.0138237">(Haddaway et al, 2015)</cite>.

Together, these grants account for around 80 % of the combined funding amounts attributed to individual principal investigators. Most of the non-matched grants were awarded to research within the humanities and social sciences, which have less extensive coverage in the WoS <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The full and the WoS-matched sample are predominantly similar in their composition.

Lower coverage than Google Scholar and Microsoft Academic is a logical outcome of the standards that journals must meet to be indexed by Scopus (e.g., <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00019">Baas, et al, 2020;</cite>Gasparyan & Kitas, 2021;<cite data-doi="10.3390/publications9010012">Pranckutė, 2021;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1201/9781315155890-3">Schotten et al, 2017)</cite> and the Web of Science (WoS) <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00018">(Birkle et al, 2020)</cite>. Nevertheless, non-English journals seem to be underrepresented in both Scopus and the Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. One source of difference between WoS and Scopus is that WoS aims to generate a balanced set of journals to support the quality of citation data used for impact evaluations <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00018">(Birkle et al, 2020)</cite>.

For ensuring the wide scope of the article selection for this review, Scopus was selected as the database. Scopus is one of the most widely used abstract and citation database as it includes many articles and abstracts from refereed journals in the domain of technology, management, medicine and social sciences (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). These refereed journals are affiliated to reputed publishing houses such as Wiley, Elsevier, Taylor and Francis, IEEE and Springer.

In search for literature on AI literacy, both peer-reviewed scholarly articles and conference papers from K-12 to higher education levels published from 2016 to 2021 through the Web of Science and Scopus were included in this review. The aforementioned databases were considered among the world's most trusted citation indices platforms for evidence-based quality scientific research and hence helped us to ensure the inclusion of quality scientific content <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The articles that contained the phrase "AI literacy" in either the title, the abstract, main text or keywords were downloaded and reviewed by the researchers.

<note n="19" place="foot" xmlns:="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> document that compared with the most comprehensive list of scholarly/academic periodicals (Ulrich's periodical directory with over 60,000 journals), WoS and Scopus cover a greater share of the journals on natural sciences, engineering, and biomedical research than of those on the social sciences and humanities. It is unclear whether this is justified by consistent and adequate quality criteria.20 WoS only covers journals that have continuously operated for several years, employ effective peer reviewing, and have been reasonably frequently cited in other high-quality research publications.</note>

It is well documented that WoS (and other major research databases) cover English‐language publications most comprehensively. The output of countries where many researchers publish in other languages is thus easily underestimated (Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>; Van Raan et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-011-0382-1">2011</cite>). By contrast, with our dependent variable “DM Share,” we can produce valid comparisons between groups of countries as long as the relatively weak assumption holds that the probability of DM‐related articles featuring in WoS compared with the probability of other articles does not systematically and strongly deviate over time between different copyright categories.

Thus, language bias should be weaker in our data than if we had assessed full articles with search terms in English. Furthermore, the evidence is that any bias in WoS has been rather stable over time for any period systematically investigated; see <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> for a recent summary of the literature. Therefore, varying country intercepts should provide a reasonable control for the combined effect of biased coverage in WoS and stable country characteristics.
On the other hand, journals in these disciplines are relatively less likely to be included by WoS (or Scopus) <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

<note place="inline" xml:id="mde3354-note-0036"><label>19</label> <label>19</label> Mongeon and Paul‐Hus (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>) document that compared with the most comprehensive list of scholarly/academic periodicals (Ulrich's periodical directory with over 60,000 journals), WoS and Scopus cover a greater share of the journals on natural sciences, engineering, and biomedical research than of those on the social sciences and humanities. It is unclear whether this is justified by consistent and adequate quality criteria.</note>

On the one hand, in these disciplines, book publications often have a relatively greater weight in determining individual researchers' career prospects, and these are not covered in our data. On the other hand, journals in these disciplines are relatively less likely to be included by WoS (or Scopus) (Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>). Another aspect of this is that qualitative empirical research is not covered well by our data.

The reason why Scopus database was chosen is that it contains a high volume of scientific documents (70 million documents) undergoing the process of peer review in which more than 5000 editors participate <cite data-doi="10.1186/1742-5581-3-1">[28]</cite>. This database presents an efficient and rapid documentation management thanks to its management tools [29], in contrast to other databases <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[30]</cite>.

The research problem formulation has the two research questions presented in the Introduction. The second step encompasses a bibliographic search in both Scopus and Web of Science (WoS) databases, as they have a significant number of indexed journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[19]</cite>. The search considers three groups of keywords defined by a combination of keywords that covers the topic broadly enough to avoid any artificial limitation of the documents obtained while providing limits to exclude undesirable results [20].

Web of Science is convenient and has good coverage of high-quality journals and proceedings in the field of natural science (Li et al, 2018;<cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00112">Visser et al, 2021)</cite>. Unlike social science, the use of Web of Science in natural science is rapidly growing and becoming a common source for literature reviews <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Given that the author's background is not robotics, using a widely used database that provides high impact literature provides credibility for this review.

The citation indexes of the WoS used in this study have limited coverage of scholarly journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite> and contain a limited number of document types, potentially excluding important modes of knowledge dissemination. We mitigate these limitations by largely focusing on proportions rather than raw counts in our results.

On the other hand, according to related studies, WOS can provide higher quality data, including a complete record of each article and detailed citation analysis, which makes data processing more efficient ( <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.techfore.2018.02.014"> Lopes and de Carvalho, 2018 </cite> ; <cite data-doi="10.31235/osf.io/42nkm"> Martín-Martín et al, 2018 </cite> ; <cite data-doi="10.1108/jocm-12-2017-0491"> Odriozola-Fernández et al, 2019 </cite> ). And in terms of social sciences and humanities, WOS is recommended because of its high proportion of exclusive journals ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016 </cite> ; <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2006.12.001"> Norris and Oppenheim, 2007 </cite> ). The core collection of Web of Science has always maintained strict journal selection standards and evaluation process, and its journal evaluation standards have been recognized by the international academic community.

The data collected in this paper comes from the Web of Science (WOS) Core Collection database ( <cite data-doi="10.3390/su11123459"> Gong et al, 2019 </cite> ). The Web of Science Core Collection is a high-quality digital database that covers a wide range of publications from different fields and is a comprehensive citation database with wide coverage ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-006-0115-z"> Archambault et al, 2006 </cite> ; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> Mongeon et al, 2016 </cite> ). Databases such as Web of Science and Scopus are the main data sources for bibliometric analysis.

The Elsevier's Scopus was selected as the source database for this study. Among the bibliographic databases, Scopus is widely recognised and the largest one that covers a wider range of journals and scholarly literature <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">28</cite> . The journal articles within the Scopus's Earth and Planetary Science category were chosen as the focus of this study.

<figdesc>Besides, broad-scale comparison reveals that Scopus exceeds Web of Science in terms of journal coverage in every disciplinary field (see<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>, on both aspects) and thus provides a more reliable basis for accurate efficiency estimations.</figdesc>

It is worth mentioning that journals of other disciplines (e.g. physics) are mature and well-structured, in some cases, surpassing those just consolidating in social sciences <cite data-doi="10.1371/journal.pone.0127502">[14,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">15]</cite>. Consequently, the selection of BMA over Science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines is grounded on the relevance of MS research to the strategic planning field, and BMA in general, nor so in the scientific maturity (i.e.

Some researchers have realized these limitations and attempted to perform the comparison more systematically. In particular, the complete lists of documents covered by the databases have been used to eliminate the selection bias (Mongeon & Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ; Visser et al, <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00112"> 2021 </cite> ). Special attention has also been paid to the correctness of citation relationships (Haunschild et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2567-8"> 2018 </cite> ; Van Eck & Waltman, 2017 ).

Together, these grants account for around 80% of the combined funding amounts attributed to individual principal investigators. Most of the nonmatched grants were awarded to research within the humanities and social sciences, which have less extensive coverage in the WoS <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The full and WoS-matched samples are predominantly similar in their composition.

To ensure a high scientific integrity, the extant literature review comprises articles retrieved from the Scopus® of Elsevier and Web of Science® of Thomson Reuters databases. These databases were selected as they capture a wide range of peer-reviewed journals, especially in the fields of Natural Sciences and Engineering (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). The following Boolean query was formulated to content search for secondary scientific studies: ((“intelligent autonomous vehicles”) AND (“supply chain” OR “supply network”) AND (“manufacturing”)).

The authors performed the keyword analysis using the words "halal" and "food" <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.01.006">(Chen and Xiao, 2016)</cite>. The analysis was carried out using the Scopus database following <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite>, who state that "Scopus includes most of the journals indexed in WoS". Two researchers performed the analysis independently.

Scopus and Web of Science are the most extensively used database in the literature search process (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">Vieira and Gomes, 2009</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-010-0185-9">Bar-Ilan, 2010</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-012-0813-7">Abrizah et al , 2013</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">Chadegani et al , 2013</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.sorms.2016.12.001">Çelik, 2016</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1155/2016/3212095">Habib et al , 2016</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>; Jabbour et al , 2017) and includes 95 percent of the researched articles (<cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.03.054">De Oliveira et al , 2017</cite>). The search was limited to peer-reviewed journals because of the rigorous quality review process that these articles go through before publication and to control the total number of articles (<cite data-doi="10.1108/09600030910996251">Natarajarathinam et al , 2009</cite>; Bhosale and Kant, 2016).

To understand which purchasing skills have been identified in the literature as most valuable, and the contextual factors that affect skill requirements, we searched the Scopus database, the largest abstract and citation database of peer-reviewed literature with precise citations (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). The Web of Science database was also searched, in order to complement the Scopus results.

This study was conducted using secondary data from Scopus website. Earlier studies have expressed the importance of Scopus database and claimed it to be better than Web of Science due to its comprehensiveness <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.tele.2017.10.010">(Montoya et al, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

Although using these citation databases introduces biases (favoring, e.g. English-language journals), there is no “suitable alternative to WoS and Scopus when it comes to performing multidisciplinary and international bibliometric analyses” (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>, p. 226). For example, Google Scholar’s “suitability for research evaluation and other bibliometric analyses has been highly questioned because of the sporadic coverage of non-English literature, various inconsistencies (e.g.

Both databases provide peer-reviewed literature with high standards of availability, updating, scientific relevance, and comprehensiveness. However, the inclusion of the Scopus database was motivated by its stronger international/non-English coverage, in addition to more extensive coverage of social science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[66]</cite>.

Another of these paradigms is the concept of Circular Economy. Despite being widely discussed in some studies <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.resconrec.2018.09.016">[48]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[49]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.resconrec.2017.08.007">[50]</cite>, this perspective allows identifying the opportunities of a new industrial revolution and sustainable practices <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.resconrec.2018.10.009">[51,</cite><cite data-doi="10.3390/socsci7120255">52]</cite>. This can be defined as an industrial economy that is regenerative and restorative by intention and design (Ellen Macarthur Foundation, 2013).

While Google Scholar offers the broadest coverage of documents, it lacks a rigorous vetting of peer-reviewed sources and has limited capacity for data extraction. Although the Web of Science has a strong reputation for quality and advanced capabilities for data extraction, its coverage of sources in education and social sciences was considered insufficient for the purposes of this review <cite data-doi="10.3102/0034654319830380">(Hallinger & Kovačević, 2019;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Therefore, this review employed the Scopus index which offered the desired mix of document quality, content coverage, and exportable bibliographic data <cite data-doi="10.1177/1094428114562629">(Zupic & Čater 2015)</cite>.

The present paper is an example of a systematic literature review <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ibusrev.2020.101717">(Paul and Criado, 2020)</cite>. Its principle asset consists in it being based on the Scopus database, containing most of the magazines and articles which also appear in WoS (Mongeon and <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The analysis included 196 articles containing the phrase NCs in the title, abstract, or keywords, and 1588 articles with the phrase HCs and 98 with both phrases.

Furthermore, it is based on Scopus analysis of all the articles that contained the selected keywords, regardless of when they were published <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.techfore.2019.119735">(Zaheer et al, 2019)</cite>. Scopus is a comprehensive database, including most of the journals indexed in WoS <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

The research has been conducted only on the basis of the Scopus database. Despite the possibility of considering additional, comparative analyses using other databases in future research, the current study is highly reliable and gives a fair presentation of the publishing reality of the discussed topic <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Therefore, it can be concluded that the strength of this article lies not only in an in-depth analysis of articles containing the investigated keywords, but also in a broad description of topics covered therein.

WoS for allowing access to more than 12,000 journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2371-5">(Costa et al, 2017)</cite> and being considered an authority in the scientific literature <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2800-0">(Yan, Liao & Chen, 2018)</cite> and Scopus for being the largest bibliometric database <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2409-8">(Filser. Silva & Oliveira, 2017;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2409-8">Silva & Oliveira, 2017)</cite>, both considered as the most relevant standard citation bases <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2889-1">(Cisneros et al, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2919-z">Tunger & Eulerich, 2018)</cite>.

However, more generally, it is difficult to estimate how many publications and actors were not considered in this analysis. <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon et al 2016)</cite>, is geographically and linguistically biased. Even if our method provides some interesting clues, further research on "peripheral" areas with different sources is needed.

In the UK the 2021 Research Evaluation Framework reference documents suggest that bibliometrics will be a major and indeed enhanced component in both suggested submission strategies and in how the review panels form judgements 1 More critically, <cite data-doi="10.1371/journal.pone.0199031">Jappe et al [2018]</cite> provides a (Sociologically focused) overview of the influence of bibliometrics and scientometrics on research evaluation and funding bodies. <cite data-doi="10.1080/08963560802176348">Levine-Clark and Gil [2008]</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">Vieira and Gomes [2009]</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-0021-2">Franceschet [2010]</cite> and <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus [2016a]</cite> -which concludes that each has advantages but all should, ideally, be used. Considerable data cleaning would be required however to create a blended database of all.

However, WOS comprises seven different databases including different information collected from journals, conferences, reports, books and books series <cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">(Chadegani et al, 2013)</cite>. In addition to this WOS include all articles types and index all authors, institutional addresses and bibliographic references for each article <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.3145/thinkepi.2016.46">Repiso and Torres-Salinas, 2016)</cite>. Moreover, De-Moya-Anegon et al (2006) explain that WOS assigns to each journal one or more thematic categories.

For this study, the WoS database was selected. This database is widely recognized for gathering reliable and multidisciplinary research, with studies recommending its use due to the high proportion of exclusive journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[83]</cite>.

Although WOSCC is one of the largest databases for peer-reviewed scientific literature and provides a comprehensive source for bibliometric studies, there are several limitations that need to be considered when querying a single database. Despite a good correlation on the number of indexed articles and citations between several databases, there are known differences among them, leading to articles and citations being missed through the use of a single indexing database <cite data-doi="10.4103/1008-682x.171582">[2,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">[11]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[12]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">[13]</cite><cite data-doi="10.24875/gmm.19005030">[14]</cite>. In our study, Scopus, WOSCC, and Pubmed were searched in all languages using multiple terms that have been used to refer to the field over the years to avoid missing cardio-oncology publications and citations.

The representativeness of databases regarding scientific activity are considerably responsible for the validity of bibliometric analyses <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[154]</cite>. Still, Hicks <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21458">[155]</cite> concludes that these databases do not entirely accurately indicate research practices in social sciences and arts and humanities due to the local nature of research and communications practices in these fields.

In our survey of publications that refer to using computation-based methods for biomass supply chain analysis, we queried the Thomson Reuters bibliographic database WoS and Elsevier's Scopus database because the two differ substantially in coverage while both being commonly used for bibliometric analysis <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[44]</cite>. To obtain the most useful result sets, we constructed queries specific to each database and for each of the three modeling methods in turn.

e bibliometric analysis provides insight and contributes to the information about the literature pertaining to a certain eld <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2765-z">(Ellegaard, 2018)</cite>, being used in many areas of research for various ends <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2015)</cite>. e importance of this type of study rests upon the fact that possessing knowledge about the people and institutions that are conducting research, as well as the locations in which this research is being published, is relevant to identify those who will be capable of providing the best conceptual or methodological contributions <cite data-doi="10.1177/0149206308319533">(Podsako et al, 2008)</cite>.

Historically, these analyses have heavily relied on Web of Science (WoS) to gather relevant publications; however, Scopus has become another invaluable source for research since its creation in 2004 because of its access to more than 20,000 journals (compared to approximately 12,000 in WoS) [ <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ejor.2015.04.002"> 25 </cite> ], more than 4,000 of which are fully open access [ 27 ]. Although Mongeon and Paul-Hus [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 28 </cite> ] remind researchers of Scopus’ limited inclusion of publications within the Arts and Humanities, they nonetheless commend its multidisciplinary database for supporting rhetorical and visual content analyses across a wide range of source types, including books, book chapters, reviews, conference papers, and articles, among others. For the purposes of our review, we limited our searches to English-language, peer-reviewed journal articles to produce a more manageable collection of results that would help us identify not only historical and current trends within the extant planning scholarship but also potential avenues for future research that would help propel the field into more human-focused directions.

The database used was Scopus, as it constituted the largest database of peer-reviewed literature in different scientific fields <cite data-doi="10.3163/1536-5050.99.3.008">[16]</cite> and, compared to other large scientific databases such as Web of Sciences (WoS), it has a greater range of journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[23]</cite>.

Moreover, we cannot observe and track any migration events that are not represented in publications indexed in Scopus. Bibliometric databases could be biased, and there could be an under-representation of some countries, scientific fields, and languages <cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">[12,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">25,</cite>33]. Also, given the fact that we are investigating a specific period of time, our data suffers from left-truncation.

According to <cite data-doi="10.1080/09537287.2015.1129464">[39]</cite>, at least two databases should be searched. The EDs used were Scopus and Web of Science (WoS) due to their complementarity <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[41]</cite>; we applied an extensive set of terms combined with the Boolean expressions "AND" and "OR". Table 1 presents the search keywords with the number of documents associated with the database.

Additionally, bibliometric analysis serves as a helpful instrument that allows researchers to convert and reconstruct qualitative data into quantitative information. Secondly, the approach has implications in terms of identifying new trends in the field <cite data-doi="10.14512/tatup.12.1.20">[29]</cite>, documenting and integrating them into the knowledge base [30]<cite data-doi="10.1080/09718923.2010.11892847">[31]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[32]</cite>. Thus, the findings and results from science mapping studies can provide new insights for scholars around the world.

SCOPUS is also a better alternative for inter-disciplinary areas of research, such as the one discussed in this <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ijproman.2014.08.007">[43]</cite>. However, it must be noted that, the WOS and SCOPUS have similar coverage when it comes to documents published in the engineering discipline <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[42]</cite>.

Data collection from published studies was critical for achieving the objectives of this study since this would help in defining which scholarly publications would be used to draw any conclusions based on findings. SCOPUS was chosen as the database for this study because it has a wider variety of coverage of research than other databases including Web of Science (WOS), Google Scholar, and PubMed, among others <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[42]</cite>. SCOPUS is also a better alternative for inter-disciplinary areas of research, such as the one discussed in this <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ijproman.2014.08.007">[43]</cite>.

This was taken from the 'Web of Science Collection', a subset of the 'Web of Science' database, which includes the Science Citation Index Expanded (SCIE), the Social Sciences Citation Index (SSCI) and the Arts and Humanities Citation Index (A&HCI). This database was chosen due to its standing in the academic world as one of the premier citation search platforms <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2622-5">[4]</cite> and has been proved to be more accurate than rivals such as Scopus in fields such as its journal classification system <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.02.003">[5,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">6]</cite>.

With the continuous update of Web of Science Core Collection, the database provider should provide more technical details about its update for users timely. Besides, users should also be aware of the features and defects of this authoritative bibliographic database which have been widely investigated in previous studies <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00018">(Birkle et al 2020;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.07.003">Franceschini et al 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2349-3">Huang et al 2017;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.07.008">Liu et al 2018b</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03362-3">Liu et al , 2020</cite>Martín-Martín et al 2018;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.23713">Tang et al 2017</cite>).

In relation to possible biases in the dataset, the use of either Elsevier's Scopus and Thomson Reuters' Web of Science (WoS) for research evaluation may introduce biases that favor Natural Sciences and Engineering as well as Biomedical Research to the detriment of Social Sciences and Arts and Humanities <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

We performed the keyword search on the Scopus and Web of Science databases to identify relevant articles published between 2001 and 2021. These two databases are multidisciplinary and reliable in encompassing an extensive range of articles in domains, such as management, technology, information systems science, psychology and consumer behavior <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. This choice of databases is consistent with prior SLRs that have been published in the fields of technology <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ijmedinf.2019.04.024">(Behera et al, 2019)</cite> and users' behaviors in cyberspace <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.techfore.2020.120426">(Kaur et al, 2020;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1108/intr-11-2019-0455">Tandon et al, 2021)</cite>.

In a recent study of comparison between PubMed, Scopus and WoS by <cite data-doi="10.3791/58494">AlRyalat et al (2019)</cite>, the Scopus search fruited in the maximum number of papers (11,444 documents), tailed by a WoS search with 10,943 documents. Scopus not only includes most of the journals that are indexed in the WoS but also have a greater number of exclusive journals compared to the WoS (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>).

The rest of the languages did not reach 1%. This result is related to the fact that publication in English broadens the audience globally, as was the case in most of the searches carried out in the Scopus database <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.esp.2011.07.003">[81,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">82]</cite>.

Scopus was searched on October 15, 2019 to retrieve SSc journal publications for its wide indexing of journals [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 17 </cite> ]. Publications with “systemic sclerosis” or “scleroderma” but not “localised/localized scleroderma” in titles or keywords were identified as SSc publications.

The rest of the languages did not reach 1%. This result is related to the fact that publication in English broadens the audience globally, as was the case in most of the searches carried out in the Scopus database <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.esp.2011.07.003">[81,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">82]</cite>. Publication increased with the inclusion of new terms related to business planning considered an uninterrupted continuous process <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.chaos.2016.03.003">[76]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1186/s11782-017-0022-6">[77]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1111/jbfa.12530">[78]</cite>, so the information needed to be constantly updated in order to take corrective measures.

Generally, the content indexed in WoS and Scopus was also shown to be highly overlapping, with Scopus indexing a greater amount of unique sources not covered by WoS [44]. However, the extent of content overlap between WoS and Scopus was determined to be varying greatly across disciplines [40,<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">47]</cite>. In cases of specific subject fields, the variations were even more noticeable.

To collect as many related journal and proceedings articles as possible, four major interdisciplinary databases were selected as article sources: Web of Science (WoS) Core Collection, ACM Digital Library, IEEE/IEE Electronic Library (IEL) Online, and Education Resources Information Center (ERIC). WoS, ACM, and IEL are important sources covering peer-reviewed scientific articles <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[16]</cite>. The ERIC database covers more than 1200 journal titles and is an authoritative collection of journal articles for the field of education [17].

Second, the database was selected. The main databases closely related to the field were consulted, such as Web Of Science, Scopus, PubMed, and Google Scholar <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">(Harzing and Alakangas, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Finally, the research articles from Scopus were selected, as it is the scientific database that has a high number of articles, authors, and journals that meet the scientific quality requirements of peer review <cite data-doi="10.5860/crl.64.6.468">(Ackerson and Chapman, 2003;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-010-0270-0">Mingers and Lipitakis, 2010)</cite>.

These studies show that the difference in journal coverage between Scopus and WoS has grown over time and that differences in coverage result in variations in research output volumes, rank and global share of different countries <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-021-03948-5">(Singh et al, 2021;</cite>Jacso, 2005;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. In <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> the authors observed that there is an over representation of certain countries and languages both in WoS and Scopus journal coverage. In addition, they show that WoS and Scopus journal coverage differ the most in Natural Science and Engineering and in Arts and Humanities fields.

Other studies compared these systems in respect to the coverage and distribution of journals and publications. These studies show that the difference in journal coverage between Scopus and WoS has grown over time and that differences in coverage result in variations in research output volumes, rank and global share of different countries <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-021-03948-5">(Singh et al, 2021;</cite>Jacso, 2005;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. In <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> the authors observed that there is an over representation of certain countries and languages both in WoS and Scopus journal coverage.

The use of the Scopus database as a source for analysis may introduce biases because Englishlanguage sources are overrepresented at the expense of other languages <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Future research as a systematic review of the water footprint in the countries of former Yugoslavia should focus on various data sources, such as Google Scholar, the Cooperative On-line Bibliographic System and Services -COBISS <cite data-doi="10.1108/03074800010304361">(Seljak and Seljak, 2000)</cite> implemented in Slovenia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, and Macedonia (Župan, 2018), or the Croatian HRČAK <cite data-doi="10.1087/20090402">(Stojanovski et al, 2009)</cite>, etc., which covers non-English scientific literature in more detail.

The Journal Impact Factor, widely recognized as a cornerstone of publication impact assessments, originated as a tool for library journal selection and collection development <cite data-doi="10.1001/jama.295.1.90">(Garfield, 2006)</cite>. Librarians select, recommend and maintain citation databases for measuring researcher impact, each of which have been shown to have differences in disciplinary coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-008-0216-y">(Bar-Ilan, 2008;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.outlook.2012.04.007">De Groote and Raszewski, 2012;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing and Alakangas, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.outlook.2017.03.004">Powell and Peterson, 2017;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">Vieira and Gomes, 2009)</cite>. Author disambiguation strategies, required for reliable author summary metrics, rely on carefully crafted search queries and author identifiers commonly championed by librarians (Carley et al, 2017;Elliott, 2010;<cite data-doi="10.1108/el-04-2016-0090">Kendall et al, 2017)</cite>.

Demonstrations were given in WoS, Scopus, and Google Scholar, all of which are available to current university students, staff and faculty. All three were included because while WoS has long been used as the standard citation source, and several recent studies have highlighted the increased coverage offered by Scopus and Google Scholar, particularly within the Arts and Humanities disciplines <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1093/reseval/rvv049">Prins et al, 2016)</cite>. However, the institutional RIM instance currently offers integration with WoS and Scopus only.

Second, our data set may underrepresent conference venues due to the coverage of the data source we used, i.e. the Web of Science (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). Some relevant bibliographic records, especially in the expanded data set, could have been omitted from our data sets.

(2) Scopus also includes indexed sources from non-English-speaking countries, and including these as part of our study was a significant contribution because non-English publications amount between 25 and 30% of academic literature in some disciplines (<cite data-doi="10.2478/jdis-2019-0001">Aksnes and Sivertsen, 2019</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z">Vera-Baceta et al , 2019</cite>). (3) Previous studies have supported the advantages of using Scopus rather than WoS bibliometric database analysis (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-007-1681-4">Moya-Anegón et al , 2007</cite>).

Scopus database was used in this study because it houses more than 30000 scientific literature items (journals, books and conference proceedings) in subject areas such as sciences, medicine, humanities and social sciences more than Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[26]</cite>. The database also contains over 20000 journal titles from more than 5000 publishers [43].

Moreover, we cannot observe and track migration events that are not represented in publications indexed in Scopus. Bibliometric databases could be biased, and some countries, scientific fields, and languages could be under-represented (Falagas et al 2008;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016;</cite>Sugimoto and Larivière 2018). This potential bias exists even though Scopus provides content in 40 languages, and 22% of the content of Scopus is published in languages other than English (Elsevier 2020).

<note n="2" place="foot" xmlns:="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Scopus is a database of peer-reviewed scientific literature(Falagas et al 2008;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite> covering 77 million citable documents, 22% of which are published in languages other than English (Elsevier 2020).</note>

In phase 2, the search process considered the Scopus and Web of Science (WoS) databases, which cover many publications, the thematic areas, and the selected range of years <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. In the strings' construction, the Boolean operators, AND and OR, were used to integrate the selected variables.

Web of Science (WOS) (https://www.webofscience.com/wos/woscc/basic-search; accessed on 3 May 2021) and Scopus (https://www.scopus.com/search/form.uri?display= basic#basic; accessed on 3 May 2021) were at the outset the chosen databases for literature search because they are most commonly used for bibliometric analysis and provide a broad interdisciplinary coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[24]</cite>. Nevertheless, after an initial search, WOS was not considered for the present study due to the limited number of obtained results.

The second limitation is that Web of Science (WoS) data sources have some biases <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016;</cite>Lucio-Arias et al 2015): publications in English, publications about Natural Sciences, Ecology and Bio-medicine, and publications authored by researchers from the Netherlands, United Kingdom and the USA are overrepresented. In contrast, all other countries and languages, and especially publications about Social Sciences and Arts & Humanities, are underrepresented.

Former studies on the Cuban scientific output in scholarly journals have dealt with limited number of major databases and web resources, short coverage of Cuban scholarly journals, narrow time frames, and focused on available bibliographic metadata, all these compromising the real data trend and source representativeness <cite data-doi="10.1007/bf02020924">(Sancho 1992;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/bf02026512">Sancho et al 1993;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1038/511155c">Araújo-Ruiz et al 2005</cite>; Arencibia-Jorge and de Moya-Anegón 2010; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. Therefore, in this work, all these limitations have been addressed.

Secondly, bibliometric analysis do not contextualize the production of articles historically nor politically which can assist in explaining the observed direction as well as the lack of studies prior to 1991. Finally, the choice of the database may geographically bias the results obtained <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. This may have limited the research included in regional databases that could contain the production of researchers from countries whose main language is different from English.

Analyses are performed considering the different levels of information that are found, which include journals, papers, authors, institutions and countries. The references were obtained considering all the documents published between 1989 and 2016 in the journals indexed in Scopus, which is considered one of the most complete databases in the social sciences <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>.

However, the analysis of the national output for developing countries put some constraints due to its lower representativeness in those databases, unless devoid of national publishing systems together with incipient scientific system's development (for instance, Dominican Republic (Riggio Olivares 2017)). This has been stressed by recommendations on the inclusion of national journals in nationwide output studies, together with database indexing <cite data-doi="10.1007/bf02020924">(Sancho 1992;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. Regarding procedure 1.4, Scopus and WoS are the most recommended indexes, by which to perform multidisciplinary and international bibliometric analyses of journal articles <cite data-doi="10.1108/14684520810865958">(Gavel and Iselid 2008;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. While Scopus is the largest bibliometric database and WoS offers the most wide-ranging coverage of science, both contain essential metadata to realize bibliometric analyses <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2409-8">Filser et al 2017)</cite>. Therefore, Scopus and WoS are appropriate sources for this research.

A unified library was further generated by progressively overlapping independent libraries. Scopus data was prioritized due to its largest coverage by source and its major indexing of sources published in Spanish <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. The overlapping sequence was: Scopus + WoS-CC + CCC + Pascal-Francis + CABI + Biosis + SciELO Citation Index + ZR + (CLASE + PERIÓDICA) + Pubmed.

WOS and Scopus are considered to be the largest citation databases available as of 2021, containing information on literature in various disciplines such as medicine, science and engineering, the humanities, and art <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[17]</cite>. The search was performed during the early days of January 2020 in two important bibliographic databases: Scopus and Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Table 2 shows the search string used in each database along with the results obtained in each of them.

WoS is also the first database in the market and one of the largest. Comparative studies show that both databases provide significant results for English language journals and are consistent with each other <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-hus, 2016)</cite>. A considerable number of bibliometric analyses use these two data sources, and recent research pointed out that the use of these two alone requires caution when comparing different fields, institutions, countries, or languages <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-hus, 2016)</cite>.

This database is part of the objective of analyzing the main trends in an area of incipient scientific intersection, such as emotions, sports and management. Therefore, Scopus was selected due that includes the majority of journals indexed in WoS and that it has a greater number of journals (and therefore references) compared to this database ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016 </cite> ). In fact, almost 84% of the articles of WoS can be found in Scopus, and the WoS database includes fewer indexed journals than Scopus, so by selecting Scopus the risk of overlooking documents during the search is reduced ( <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jclepro.2019.119742"> Terán-Yépez et al, 2020 </cite> ).

Although we considered using other databases such as the Web of Science, which is also recognized by the scienti c community, studies point to the fact that both have similar coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">(Harzing and Alakangas, 2016)</cite>. us, the decision was made to use only Scopus, as it is considered one of the main data sources <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2015)</cite> and the use of a second database with similar coverage would not bring signi cantly di erent results. Data collection happened in January of 2019 and the search was conducted with the terms "sharing economy", "collaborative economy" and "collaborative consumption" in the article title, abstract and keywords elds.

The decision to use Scopus over other databases (i.e., Web of Science [WoS], ScienceOpen, and others) was based on the amount of titles that Scopus includes in its collections. Various evaluations of the two largest databases (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-014-1506-1">Cavacini, 2015</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">Chadegani et al, 2013</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>) note that Scopus covers more journals than WoS and that most of the journals contained in the later are also contained in Scopus. The information was manually cleaned by visually checking each citation to avoid overlap due to misspellings or slight variations used for journal names, which is important for a correct statistical analysis.

Journal of Data and Information Science Science (SCIE, SSCI, and AHCI) covered 94 and 73 percent, respectively of the journal publications. However, the studies have important differences in research design: while our study analyses the population of individual publications, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> investigate the coverage by publication channels based on journal lists (cf. point b above).

However, this bias is found to be even larger within the Web of Science, which may have served as an alternative data source. Besides, broad-scale comparison reveals that Scopus exceeds Web of Science in terms of journal coverage in every disciplinary field (see <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>, on both aspects) and thus provides a more reliable basis for accurate efficiency estimations. We must acknowledge that bibliometric metadata are not produced for use as research data, and like most sources of big data, they are not immune to potential biases or errors. However, within the context of individual-level bibliometric data, Scopus claims to provide greater coverage (Elsevier 2020) and higher precision (Paturi and Loktev 2020) than its counterparts (Falagas et al 2008;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. With our conservative approach of inferring migration from changes of the mode countries as opposed to all changes of affiliation <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.11.002">(Robinson-García et al 2019)</cite>, our results are expected to be less sensitive to issues of precision flaws.

The initial search starts with the selection of three databases: Scopus, IEEEXplore, and ScienceDirect. These databases have wide coverage of articles related to the topic and allow to filter the results: according to <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[14]</cite>, in the social sciences, the coverage of Scopus is much higher than that of the Web of Science; The percentage of titles covered only by Scopus is above 60%, to which is added the almost 40% coverage overlap (Scopus and WoS), with WoS alone covering a very small percentage of titles; Sources indexed only by WoS are not necessarily disposable, however, it is safe to use only Scopus. IEEExplore and Science Direct were used because they are widely used databases in the area of information systems, as a cross-check measure with Scopus results.

Although the new-comer Scopus was launched in 2004, it is a powerful competitor of WoS and is attempting to challenge the dominating role of WoS. Various studies have compared these two databases from different perspectives <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2569-6">(Abdulhayoglu & Thijs 2018;</cite>Adriaanse & Rensleigh 2013;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing & Alakangas 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.09.002">Martín-Martín et al 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21165">Meho & Sugimoto 2009;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2769-8">Moed et al 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.02.003">Wang & Waltman 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2980-7">Zhu et al 2019a</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03091-2">Zhu et al , 2019b</cite>. However, to the best of our knowledge, no empirical study has been conducted focusing on the use of Scopus in academic papers let alone a comparative study about both of them.

WoS data sources have some biases <cite data-doi="10.11606/issn.2316-9036.v0i89p26-61">(Packer 2011;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016;</cite>Lucio-Arias et al 2015),, as publications in English, publications about Natural Sciences, Ecology and Bio-medicine, and publications authored by researchers from the Netherlands, United Kingdom, and the USA are overrepresented. In contrast, all other countries and languages are underrepresented <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03266-x">(Belli and Baltà 2019</cite>).

Many institutions assess researchers by the quantity and quality of their published research. Using databases such as the Web of Science or Scopus, bibliometrics data can be easily obtained and statistically analyzed for different disciplines <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. It is a useful method for assessing a field of research within academic publications, and has recently been used to assess networks of knowledge production and epistemic communities <cite data-doi="10.1038/nclimate2782">(Corbera et al 2016)</cite>.

Because most researchers do not have the possibility to retrieve large amounts of data from data sources such as Scopus and WoS, bibliographic data sources are typically compared in small-scale case studies, focusing for instance on documents in a specific research field or on a small number of researchers and the documents they have authored (e.g., <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03114-y">Harzing, 2019)</cite>. A large-scale comparison of Scopus and WoS was presented by <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite>. A similar comparison, including not only Scopus and WoS but also Dimensions, was carried out by Singh, Singh et al (2020).

Scopus is one of the world’s largest databases of international multidisciplinary collections of peer-reviewed research publications comprising more than 22,000 journals, books, and conference proceedings from four main knowledge fields: life sciences, physical sciences, health sciences, and social sciences and humanities. We selected Scopus due to its high number of titles included in its collections, which surpasses other sources (<cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">Chadegani et al, 2013</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). Results were manually refined discarding misspellings or slight variations used for journal names, which is important for a correct assignment of the SJR indicator and h -index.

Among the limitations of this article, it is observed that the criteria for text selection left out published papers that have been presented in congresses, as well as books and scientific articles not classified by the Web of Science and SCOPUS databases. Despite the significant representativeness, if the choice not to search local databases and specific areas, on the one hand, privileged interdisciplinary and international studies, on the other, brought as a limitation the predominance of English language studies and researches inserted in the disciplines of the Exact Sciences field, to the detriment of other areas and national indexes, as pointed out by <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite>.

Scopus and CWTS WoS are dominated by documents written in English (see also <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Although they cover a small share of documents written in languages such as Chinese, French, German, Portuguese, and Spanish, 90% of the documents in Scopus and 96% of the documents in CWTS WoS are in English.

In our opinion, such a “true” value does not exist; the h -value is database-dependent. Several bibliometric studies have pointed to (large) differences between the databases, which are mainly driven by different coverages of the literature leading to different citation counts for one and the same paper (e.g., Harzing and Alakangas <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9"> 2015 </cite> ; Mongeon and Paul-Hus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ).

The parameters that may inform the proposed decision-making approach are grounded on a synthesis of the existing literature that involves scientific publications for addressing the defined research questions <cite data-doi="10.28945/479">(Levy and Ellis 2006)</cite>. To identify relevant papers, Boolean searches using appropriate keywords in the Scopus® of Elsevier and Web of Science® of Thomson Reuters databases were performed as they offer a broad range of peer-reviewed journals in the fields of Natural Sciences and Engineering <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. The terms 'renewable feedstock' and 'renewable chemical feedstock' were searched either separately or in combination with the terms 'supply chain', 'supply network', 'supply chain design' and 'supply chain management' using either the 'Article Title' or 'Article Title, Abstract, Keywords' categories.

Scopus was preferred to alternative bibliographic databases (e.g. Web of Science) because it has been found to have slightly greater coverage of non-STM disciplines <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>), something we considered important given the likelihood of OA-related research appearing in social science journals. Google Scholar is a freely available search engine which indexes an estimated 160 million scholarly documents (Orduna-Malea, Ayllón, Martín-Martín, & Delgado López-Cózar, 2015).

Earlier studies showed that the vast majority of environmental evidence reviews relied on limited bibliographic sources,<cite data-doi="10.1016/j.envsci.2016.06.012 10.1111/faf.12196"> 14,15 </cite> presumably because academic institutions have access to such platforms for educational and research purposes, and therefore academic researchers are familiar with them, and if, for example, resources are limited (eg, time, funding) or reviewers are unwilling to carry out supplementary searches (eg, web‐based searches, contacting experts and stakeholders), certain bibliographic platform(s) are used as the sole source for searching literature. A major problem in using single bibliographic platforms as search sources is that they contain only selected records from all existing data (ie, records selectively made available to users as a service) with a very strong preference for commercially published articles,<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 13 </cite> and therefore it is possible that meta‐analytical estimates relying on such practice will be affected (Figure 1). In other words, studies indexed in such bibliographic platform(s) may not represent the true population of relevance, hence the impacts of availability bias—intentional or unintentional selective sampling of studies that are easily accessible to samplers<cite data-doi="10.1002/jrsm.1120"> 16,17 </cite>—on overall mean effect sizes may be observed.

As a result, their samples of publishers and their journal counts diverge significantly. Web of Science, for instance, is more exclusive than Scopus which, however, is not promiscuous neither <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>; like other databases, it instead proclaims a set of criteria that are to be fulfilled before a publisher can have its journals indexed, leading to potentially large-scale omissions. 1 Smaller catalogues follow their specific rationales and thus do not intend to achieve an all-inclusive overview of the landscape of scientific publishing.

This "comprehensiveness" of SCOPUS over Web of Science can be seen in this example: When the search string ("Industry 4.0" OR "digital technolog*" OR "manufactur* data" OR "digital intelligen*") AND ("circular econom*") was entered into both databases, Web of Science returned four results and SCOPUS returned 14 results for the period selected "All Years". Google Scholar was not utilized as valid questions still persist in terms of its suitability for research evaluation due to the low data quality found in Google Scholar <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[70]</cite>.
