The most common non-English language is Chinese, which constitutes 2.1% of the total, followed by Portuguese (0.8%). The reason for this finding is that Scopus has a better coverage of English language journal than those in other languages <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[44]</cite>. A previously published study on aflatoxin <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.foodcont.2018.02.017">[28]</cite> had shown different results (5122 documents worldwide from 1963 to 2016) from those presented in the current study.

BioRxiv accepts submissions only in English, and the primary motivation for this work was the attention being paid to bioRxiv by organizations based mostly in the U.S. and western Europe. In addition, bibliometrics databases such as Scopus and Web of Science have well-documented biases in favor of English-language publications (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-006-0115-z">Archambault et al 2006</cite>; de <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-007-1681-4">Moya-Anegón et al 2007</cite>), which could have an effect on observed publication rates and the bioRxiv adoption scores that depend on scientific output derived from Scopus.

This is understandable since adaptation measures taken by developed countries were still very limited even in 2011 <cite data-doi="10.1007/s10584-011-0045-5">[32]</cite>. <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[41]</cite>. Case studies make up most of the academic articles.

• Ulrich's Periodicals Directory has also been used as an external reference, again with no assertion that it represents academic standards for evaluation <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

However, WoS is a more selective index, since it includes about 18,200 journals and proceedings in its Core Collection. According to Mongeon and Paul-Hus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[9]</cite>, there were exactly 13,605 journals in WoS in 2014. With about 22,800 serial titles, 20,346 of which are journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[9]</cite>, Scopus is more inclusive.

Data about research articles with at least one author affiliated with a Finnish university was retrieved from the national Juuli database, which annually collects publication data from all Finnish universities. Juuli provides a unique and comprehensive national data set of the research publications, in contrast to those found in Web of Science and Scopus (see <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2015)</cite>. Information from 114,496 publications published from 2012 through 2014 was retrieved.

This role notwithstanding, the coverage and data quality of available citation indexes present challenging limitations, as alluded to above. For example, both the Web of Science and Scopus focus mainly on English-language journals; they also introduce a strong bias in favour of natural sciences and biomedical research, to the detriment of the social sciences and humanities <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21458">(Hicks & Wang, 2011;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). These biases have an undeniable effect on the reward system of science, since they lead to the underrepresentation or even invisibility of scholars, particularly from non-English speaking countries and non-article-centred disciplines, where monographs, for example, might be highly regarded in traditional peer-review evaluations (such as most of the humanities).

Literature survey was performed between April and July 2018 in Scopus, as the coverage of Scopus on the number of papers in most disciplines is a bit higher than in another widely used Web of Science (WoS) database (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing & Alakangas, 2016</cite>). In addition, Scopus covers larger proportion of journals in the fields of Biomedical Research and Natural Sciences and Engineering than WoS database (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). The Google Scholar database was omitted from our survey although its coverage is even higher, but there might be many duplicate records and the quality of indexed material is more variable as the quality control process is not as strong as in Scopus or WoS (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing & Alakangas, 2016</cite>).

Scopus is considered the biggest repository of peer-reviewed literature and includes the most relevant publications of the subject field of study. Furthermore, it is the database that provides the most information on each author, institution, and country <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

A bibliometric approach was used for this study in order to analyze research documents on the presence of women in company boards, using metadata extracted from the Web of Science. This database is one of the most important of its kind, since it includes the most influential academic publications used in bibliometric and scientometric studies <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[44]</cite> and indexes a large number of articles published in the primary academic journals from all over the world [45]. The main collection of the Web of Science contains over 76 million records and over 1600 million cited references [46].

Although traditional bibliometric analysis uses the Web of Science (WoS) database, when the research topic is limited, the Scopus database is recommended, since it has wider coverage than the WoS (Zupic & Čater, <cite data-doi="10.1177/1094428114562629">2015</cite>). Indeed, Scopus includes most of the journals indexed in the WoS database but a greater number of high‐impact journals (Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>).

Systematic comparisons between WoS and Scopus therefore emerged as a new topic for bibliometric investigation <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2007.11.001">(Bar-Ilan 2008)</cite>. Despite the growing number of comparative studies on this topic -for example those by <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.iedeen.2016.02.001">Sánchez, Del Río Rama and García (2017)</cite> and <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">Vieira and Gomes (2009)</cite> -systematic comparisons of the article coverage of Scopus and WoS for countries and institutions in sub-Saharan Africa remain critically absent. One exception is a comparative study of Moi University (Kenya) and the University of Zululand (South Africa), which established that the publications of approximately 70% of academics at the two institutions were in neither Scopus nor WoS (Ocholla, Mostert & Rotich 2016).

The article uses the WoS Core Collection database in the search process of the information. We remark that there are other databases for dealing with academic documents <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Note that WoS is owned by the company Thomson & Reuters Corporation.

Taking into account that we are working with two databases, it is necessary to carry out an analysis of the overlap between both and their level of singularity. According to Mongeon & Paul-Hus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[38]</cite> (p. 2013), "while both databases share biases, their coverage differs substantially". 340 articles were identified in WoS and 402 in Scopus were related to Water Governance.

The Scopus citation index was used to estimate the prevalence and citation impact of international research about the chosen websites. Scopus was used in preference to the Web of Science because it has wider coverage, and particularly for non-English and non-Western sources <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Scopus queries were used to identify articles mentioning one of the top 20 websites.

Despite covering a substantial amount of the academic literature, no database is complete and balanced (Chadegani et al , <cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">2013</cite>). Both databases contain biases that favour the frequency of natural, biomedical and engineering sciences over AH and SS (Mongeon & Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>). To control for this potential limitation and increase the reliability of our analysis (i.e., comparing the number of papers published using the terms searched across different research areas), the number of articles published was standardized by the total number of papers published in each research area as follows: the standardized number of publications reflects the number of papers published using target terms ( n ) per total number of papers published in the research area ( N ) multiplied by one million (standard factor; i.e., expressed by papers per million papers):<formula rend="display"></formula>

So, we believe that this impact is not of great importance and the results obtained from SCOPUS are representative enough to be used in a bibliometric study as the one we have performed. In fact, SCOPUS is one of the most commonly-used sources for citation data in bibliometric analyses <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[29]</cite> .

Bibliometric research <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite> suggests that the largest indexing services currently are Elsevier's Scopus (with a bias towards researchers in Europe) and Clarivate's Web of Science (with a bias towards researchers in the US). While neither is a strict subset of the other, Scopus seems to have a slightly larger coverage (22,800 + journals 4 as opposed to Web of Science's 20,300 + 5 ).

One limitation comes from the use of publication data from WoS to populate our list of authors and papers for the matching. As <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> reported, some the journals in Arts and Humanities and Social Sciences are underrepresented in WoS, and so are journals in languages other than English or published in countries other than the UK, the USA, the Netherlands, Germany, Switzerland, and France. Moreover, WoS does not include books, which are still one of the main means of knowledge dissemination in arts and humanities and, to a lesser extent, in social sciences <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.20349">(Larivière et al, 2006)</cite>.

In this work, the Scopus database was chosen as it is considered the largest repository of data on citations and summaries of peer-reviewed literature, also providing great availability <cite data-doi="10.3390/su10041084">[45]</cite>. Furthermore, Scopus includes more indexed journals than WoS <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[53]</cite>; it is remarkable that, while 84% of the WoS indexed titles can be found in Scopus, only 54% of the Scopus indexed publications are found in WoS <cite data-doi="10.1108/14684520810865958">[54]</cite>.

Both of these aspects are of highly pragmatic significance for policymakers and the users of scientific databases. Years later, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> Mongeon and Paul-Haus (2016) </cite> revisited the issue and compared the coverage of WoS and Scopus to examine whether preexisting biases (such as language, geography, and theme) were still to be found in Scopus. They concluded that some biases still remained in both databases and stated that this should be taken into account in assessing scientific activities.

In general, the contents indexed in WoS and Scopus also showed a lot of overlap, with Scopus indexing a larger number of unique sources that were not recorded by WoS [45]. A largescale comparison at the journal level has shown that WoS and Scopus gravitate towards the natural sciences, engineering, and biomedical research, and Scopus offers broader coverage of all areas studied, particularly biomedical research <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[46]</cite>. However, the absolute majority of these studies report better coverage of Scopus from all important disciplines compared to WoS <cite data-doi="10.2478/jdis-2019-0001">[47]</cite>.

However, it also includes non-academic work, and the bibliometric quality of the listings is less reliable (e.g., it includes multiple versions of working papers or unpublished work). Finally, it should be noted that despite differences between the publication databases <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.02.007">Waltman, 2016)</cite>, a recent study by <cite data-doi="10.31235/osf.io/42nkm">Martín-Martín (2018)</cite> showed that the correlation between citations counts of the database are relatively high. Additionally, these differences are less relevant for our study as we focus on the most important articles (measured by citation) and not the overall population of articles, for this comparison should be even lower.

A comparison of the various databases used to assess the consistency of the research impact metrics has been an active area of research in recent years (e.g. <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-008-0216-y">Bar-Ilan, 2008</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.23080">Haley, 2014</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzig and Alakangas, 2016</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-010-0270-0">Mingers and Lipitakis, 2010</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). For this paper, all researchers' impact metrics were accessed using Google Scholar , unless the researcher was not registered, then impact metrics from Publish or Perish were used; this non-registration issue via Google Scholar only occurred in a small number of cases.

According to <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.envpol.2019.113221">Braun et al (2019)</cite> <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.envpol.2019.113221">[49]</cite>, WoS and Scopus are the most transparent and reliable bibliometric tools, which makes them the most comprehensive scientific databases for publication visualization and research analysis <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.envpol.2019.113221">[49]</cite>. Scopus is counted as one of the best publication databases because of its large range of journal articles and multidisciplinary studies <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[50,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.autcon.2017.12.002">51]</cite>. On the other hand, the WoS core collection includes several citation indexes, such as the Science (SCIE), Arts and Humanities (A&HCI), Social Sciences (SSCI), and Conference Proceedings (CPCI) Citation Indexes, which include high-quality articles for performing a systematic review and bibliometric analysis <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.120581">[52,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jclepro.2019.01.058">53]</cite>.

Every classification system will demarcate subjects differently, even when the subjects are titled the same way. Previous assessments of the subject coverage of Scopus and WOS CC used Scopus’ ASJC at the five-category level (Visser et al, <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00112"> 2021 </cite> ), Google Scholar categories at the 252 and eight-category levels (Martín-Martín et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2820-9"> 2018a </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.09.002"> 2018b </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03690-4"> 2021 </cite> ), the National Science Foundation classification at the four-category level (Mongeon & Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ), WOS classification at the five-category level (Singh et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-021-03948-5"> 2021 </cite> ) or not closer specified classifications at the four-category level ( Aksnes & Sivertsen, <cite data-doi="10.2478/jdis-2019-0001"> 2019 </cite> ) and self-specified classifications at the five-category level (Harzing & Alakangas, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9"> 2016 </cite> ). As it is difficult to identify the best classification system, a multitude of different approaches might encourage better research classifications by comparing and learning (Wang & Waltman, <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.02.003"> 2016 </cite> ).

Fourth, an important question is how subject coverage is determined in terms of multi- or single-attribution. Most of the studies found comparing the subject coverage of Scopus and WOS CC assume one record is unequivocally attributable to a single subject: For example, Mongeon and Paul-Hus ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ) assume journals are categorizable into one of four disciplines, and Martín-Martín et al ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03690-4"> 2021 </cite> ) assume cited documents share the same single subject the seed document was classified against under the Google Scholar categories. Nevertheless, records are often attributable to more than one subject.

Next to the number of databases that are compared, these studies differ in which data they analyze. Some analyze databases via journals (Harzing, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03114-y"> 2019 </cite> ; Mongeon & Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ; Moya-Anegón et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-007-1681-4"> 2007 </cite> ; Singh et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-021-03948-5"> 2021 </cite> ) or individual records (Vera-Baceta et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z"> 2019 </cite> ) and their citations (Martín-Martín et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2820-9"> 2018a </cite> ). The goal is to assess language coverage (Vera-Baceta et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z"> 2019 </cite> ), geographic coverage (Singh et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-021-03948-5"> 2021 </cite> ), record type coverage, subject coverage, (Martín-Martín et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2820-9"> 2018a </cite> ; Meho & Yang, <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.20677"> 2007 </cite> ), journal coverage, citation coverage (García-Pérez, <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21372"> 2010 </cite> ) or a mix of those (Harzing, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03114-y"> 2019 </cite> ; Harzing & Alakangas, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9"> 2016 </cite> ; Moya-Anegón et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-007-1681-4"> 2007 </cite> ; Singh et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-021-03948-5"> 2021 </cite> ; Visser et al, <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00112"> 2021 </cite> ).

It has a broader and more robust cover-to-cover indexing policy than Web of Science and offers the best choice amongst the multidisciplinary databases with citation indexing (Norris and Oppenheim 2007 ). Scopus has better coverage as compared to Web of Science (Martín-martín et al 2019 ; Mongeon and Paul-Hus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ). Comerio and Strozzi ( 2019 ), who have collected preliminary data for their study from Scopus, highlight that Scopus has 60% more content coverage than Web of Science.

To address this problem, our study aims to organize and integrate the scholarly knowledge base relating to incubators and to explore the main antecedents and characteristics of incubators as well as their impact and performance. To this end, we conduct a bibliometric analysis that is commonly used for reviewing a particular research field <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite> and for providing an overview of previous research <cite data-doi="10.3390/su11133606">(Guo et al 2019)</cite>. This bibliometric analysis can also be useful for practitioners who require information on what implications business incubators can have on new ventures or regional development.

As institutions must pay substantial fees to access these paywalled systems, particular attention has recently been directed at their disciplinary coverage, among other important characteristics (e.g. Aksnes & Sivertsen, <cite data-doi="10.2478/jdis-2019-0001"> 2019 </cite> ; Bakkalbasi et al, <cite data-doi="10.1186/1742-5581-3-7"> 2006 </cite> ; Chadegani et al, <cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18"> 2013 </cite> ; Harzing, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03114-y"> 2019 </cite> ; Harzing & Alakangas, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9"> 2016 </cite> ; Kousha & Thelwall, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-008-0217-x"> 2008 </cite> ; Martín-Martín et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2820-9"> 2018a </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.09.002"> 2018b </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03690-4"> 2021 </cite> ; Meho & Yang, <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.20677"> 2007 </cite> ; Mongeon & Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ; Moskaleva & Akoev, 2019 ; Singh et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-021-03948-5"> 2021 </cite> ; Vera-Baceta et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z"> 2019 </cite> ; Vieira & Gomes, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0"> 2009 </cite> ; Visser et al, <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00112"> 2021 </cite> ).

Scopus’ ASJC classification has many merits, particularly compared to its peer and rival the Web of Science classification (for a comparison, see Wang & Waltman, <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.02.003"> 2016 </cite> ). While Scopus, has slightly better coverage than WOS CC (for the versions available to me—see Table 2 ), this was only marginally relevant for the selection of Scopus/ASJC (Gusenbauer, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2958-5"> 2019 </cite> ; Mongeon & Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ). A more important argument for Scopus as the reference system of choice is that it does not differentiate in institutional coverage packages, while WOS offers tailored database packages, which complicates comparison.

Third, because of the great relevance of coverage as a decisive factor for optimal database choice, a considerable number of scientometrics studies analyze the coverage of databases. Some analyze single databases (Hug & Braendle, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2535-3"> 2017 </cite> ), some compare pairs (Chadegani et al, <cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18"> 2013 </cite> ; Mongeon & Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ; Moya-Anegón et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-007-1681-4"> 2007 </cite> ), triples (García-Pérez, <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21372"> 2010 </cite> ; Harzing & Alakangas, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9"> 2016 </cite> ; Martín-Martín et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2820-9"> 2018a </cite> ; Singh et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-021-03948-5"> 2021 </cite> ), or up to five or six databases (Harzing, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03114-y"> 2019 </cite> ; Martín-Martín et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03690-4"> 2021 </cite> ; Visser et al, <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00112"> 2021 </cite> ). Next to the number of databases that are compared, these studies differ in which data they analyze.

We performed a search on the Scopus database, which is one of the most important instruments for collecting systematic information on global scientific literature and is especially useful for mapping an emergent field of research, as it is not limited to ISI (International Scientific Indexing) journals. We are aware that the ISI Web of Science includes a more restricted number of journals, with less coverage of the social science field (Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>). However, we double‐checked all documents retrieved from both databases to improve the robustness of our analysis.

The liberal approach evident in Scopus with regard to assigning subjects to its records has been criticized (Mongeon & Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ; Wang & Waltman, <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.02.003"> 2016 </cite> ). This study not only confirms these previous findings but also shows subjects are attributed unevenly.

The indeed very large general information services WoS and Scopus are, compared to personal literature lists of researchers, quite incomplete <cite data-doi="10.1108/oir-07-2014-0159">(Hilbert et al 2015)</cite>. There is also a pronounced unequal coverage of certain disciplines <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite> and many languages (except English) <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z">(Vera-Baceta et al 2019)</cite>. Perhaps these facts, in particular, prevent representatives of the disadvantaged disciplines and languages (including German-and we asked German professors) from a high estimation of the relevance of their h-index as important on these platforms.

For the Web of Science, the number of papers that met the conditions above and the number of authors affiliated with Kyutech were 1430 and 288, respectively. These values were greater for Scopus (1653 and 354) reflecting that journal coverage is wider in Scopus than in the Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[18]</cite>. To ensure the data quality, the authors were restricted to tenure faculty members; non-tenure faculty members and students were excluded from the analysis.

Such a collection was acquired from more than 5000 international publishers. The authors of <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11365-017-0487-y">[42]</cite> claimed after <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[45]</cite> that the Scopus indexes most of the journals, which are also indexed in the WoS database, and a greater number of exclusive journals compared to the WoS. In fact, more than 21,100 journals are collected in the WoS database, which constitutes slightly lower quantity than in the Scopus [46].

2013, 2017 <cite data-doi="10.3390/books978-3-03842-334-8-3">[7]</cite> (p. <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11365-017-0487-y">42,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">45)</cite> Sustainable business model is a representation of business elements, their interrelations and the systemic context that enable sustainable value exchange with stakeholders towards corporate sustainability performance, translating and providing feedback between corporate strategy and operations.

We excluded two categories for being too general (Medicine (all) and Medicine (miscellaneous)) and one for having only 19 qualifying articles (Reviews and References (medical)). We chose Scopus rather than the Web of Science to get a larger collection of articles [<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">24</cite>]. Medline seems to be more inclusive than Scopus, but its inclusion of apparently lower quality research would degrade the quality of the field normalisation used.

As <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.respol.2010.10.001">Bolli and Somogyi (2011)</cite> have found, technology transfer activities can have an impact on the relation observed between third party funding and basic research output. Another limitation comes from the lower coverage of the SS research output in the Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-006-0115-z">(Archambault et al 2006;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.20349">Larivière et al 2006;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus 2015)</cite>. Since researchers in SS are more likely than those in Health or NSE to write books or publish in local journals not included in the Web of Science, a significant part of their output could not be taken into account in this study.

Researchers for which no publications were found as well as those with the same number of publications in two or more disciplines were categorized according to their department. We decided to exclude AH researchers from our analysis considering the poor coverage of Arts and Humanities publications in the Web of Science described in previous studies (e.g., <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.20349">Larivière et al 2006;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus 2015)</cite>. Therefore, this paper focuses on the remaining three disciplines: SS, NSE and Health.

The first limitation of this article related to sample selection is that it only analyses scientific journal articles and reviews published in journals indexed in Clarivate Analytics' SCIE, SSCI, and A&HCI. These three citation indexes are known to have limited coverage of journals in the Social Sciences, Arts, and Humanities (SSAH), and to suffer from a bias towards Englishlanguage journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1023/a:1010549719484">Van Leeuwen, Moed, Tijssen, Visser, & Van Raan, 2001)</cite>. Therefore, results might have been different if more articles published in journals in the SSAH that are not covered by these indexes, and/or more articles from journals that publish in languages other than English had been included in the sample.

First, the Scopus database's comprehensive coverage against other databases such as Web of Science makes it an ideal choice for this study <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.aap.2019.105387">(Bamel et al, 2020;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ijpe.2015.01.003">Fahimnia et al, 2015;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jbusres.2015.10.033">Rey-Martı ´et al, 2016)</cite>. Second, the empirical evidence emphasizes Scopus to have extensive coverage than Web of Science regarding the research areas' sources, excluding medical and physical sciences <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ijpe.2015.01.003">(Fahimnia et al, 2015;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Third, since prior research reveals that the Scopus database captures reputable and influential international journals <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ijpe.2015.01.003">(Fahimnia et al, 2015)</cite> Figure 1 Evaluation framework of this study and peer-reviewed journals constitute the prime source of the articles included in this study, we have selected Scopus as the database for this study.

The choice does not affect the validity of the scientometric investigation, as explained above. Moreover, many previous scientometric studies have been based on Scopus, and Scopus has been recognized as a better choice for interdisciplinary research topics, such as NLP in AECO and NLP and BIM, than Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.autcon.2019.01.010">[57,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">58]</cite>.

We used Scopus as a database for collecting cases since it is the largest relevant database in the field of Social Sciences. Nearly all journals included in the alternative, Web of Science, are also included in Scopus, while the opposite is not true <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. From the resulting lists of publications, the articles that met the following criteria were selected:

For example, Google Scholar’s “suitability for research evaluation and other bibliometric analyses has been highly questioned because of the sporadic coverage of non-English literature, various inconsistencies (e.g. indexation of non-existing journals) in the data, and a lack of transparency of the coverage” (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>, p. 226). Moreover, both Scopus and WoS provide access to leading IS journal articles and conference papers (Vom Brocke et al , 2009).

The Scopus database was chosen to carry out this research due to its recognized coverage (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). The search strategy was elaborated from the literature on university–industry cooperation (<cite data-doi="10.2139/ssrn.2596018">Ankrah and Al-Tabbaa, 2015</cite>; Vries et al, 2019) and SMEs (<cite data-doi="10.1002/cjas.1419">Ribau et al, 2018</cite>), as presented in Table 1.

While there is an abundant literature on the comparison between Scopus, WoS and other generalist databases (see, for example, in a national production context: <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-013-1148-8">Bartol et al, 2014;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2769-8">Moed, Markusova & Akoev, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">Archambault et al, 2009;</cite> or for a statistical comparison of large reference databases: <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite>Pranckuté, 2021;<cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00112">Visser et al, 2021)</cite>, our study provides a detailed quantitative view in the specific context of French research. Far from identifying a source that would be optimal, our study shows the importance of diversifying the sources used to provide complementary views on a country's publication.

The metadata are standardized and allow for efficient searching. However, the coverage of science, technology and medicine (STM) and of English-language publications in international journals is privileged, while other disciplinary fields, other languages of publication, other sources or document types are less fully surveyed (Van Leeuwen et al, 2001;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z">Vera-Baceta, Thelwall & Kousha, 2019)</cite>. Moreover, these databases are accessible only by subscription, so their data are not open or reusable.

While not an academic study, the previously mentioned European Open Science Monitor provided by the European Commission is a resource for regularly updated country-level metrics on OA development (European Commission, 2019). The use of Scopus data provided by Elsevier for the underlying journal publication data comes with limitations on the index coverage as well as potential conflicts of interest, with Elsevier being the largest scholarly journal publisher with a large ongoing influence on the OA landscape <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2015;</cite>Tennant, 2018). The monitor presents its results split into two categories: gold OA and green OA.

Further, the Scopus database was selected because it includes over 75 million records and more than 24,600 titles in the areas of science, technology, medicine, social sciences, art and humanities <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ecoleng.2011.02.011">2</cite> . Scopus was preferred over Web of Science (WoS) because Scopus includes most of the journals indexed in WoS and has a larger number of exclusive journals than WoS in all fields <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[44]</cite>. The Google Scholar was not originally searched since the search target comprises peer-reviewed articles only and not in publications such as grey literature, presentations, keynotes, extended abstracts, etc.

Step 1 is to decide whether WoS FA information is the appropriate data to address the research question. In addition to the well-known coverage biases of datasets <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-012-0828-0">(Liang et al, 2013;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/leap.1089">Liu, 2017;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>, the results show that these biases in FA information persist in all four citation indexes to varying extents by time coverage, language and document types. For example, the FA data in WoS have been more systematically collected for the SCIE since 2009, for the SSCI since 2015, for the A&HCI since 2017, and for the ESCI since 2015.

English is the lingua franca of global scholarly communication. It is well known that WoS indexes a disproportionately large share of records published in English <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-012-0828-0">(Liang, Rousseau, & Zhong, 2013;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/leap.1089">Liu, 2017;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2577-6">Liu et al, 2018a;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Non-English publications are only eligible for WoS indexation when their title, abstract and bibliographic information are available in English.

Scopus database was chosen to carry out this study since a comparison of Scopus and Web of Science revealed that Scopus had more journal coverage than WoS <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[44]</cite>. Elsevier Co. produces the Scopus database, which is an abstract and indexing database.

Scopus has been considered a very good alternative to the WoS since it has been designed for literature search and citation analysis <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.20677">(Meho & Yang, 2007;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">Vieira & Gomes, 2009)</cite>. Moreover, as <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> noted, Scopus includes most of the journals indexed in the WoS and has a greater number of premier journals than the WoS.

Its purpose was to provide general direction and assistance to the most prolific and impactful studies in the OCB field. Second, we conducted this analysis based on Scopus data, which covers comprehensive information on research from the social sciences (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). However, we can not assure that our search strategy contains all significant journal articles since some important information might have been omitted through the occurrence of “stray citations.” Some important information might have been omitted, endemic to all bibliometric databases (<cite data-doi="10.1108/14684520810914043">Jacsó, 2008</cite>).

Nonetheless, both WOS and Scopus databases have been found to underrepresent journals from the field of Social Sciences, as well as overrepresent journals published in English, and in countries such as the United States, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, France, Germany and Switzerland (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). The utility of using bibliographic analysis needs to be balanced with consideration of these limitations during analysis and interpretation – other relevant research that exists might simply not be accessible due to language or availability barriers when using these two databases.

The compelling reason to choose Scopus as the primary source of bibliometric records for this study is that Scopus is recognized as the largest abstract and citation database of peer-reviewed literature covering wide-ranging disciplines. Also, it is considered one of the complete databases in the social sciences <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Even though the Web of Science (WoS) has been used traditionally as the major source of scientific evaluation.

The Scopus database was used in this study due to its larger journal coverage, as well as the number of journals in terms of publishing countries and language when compared to Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

<note place="inline" xml:id="fn002">2. Scopus is a convenient, widely used and robust database when compared to other databases such as Web of Science (WoS) and Google Scholar (Bosman et al , 2006). Furthermore, a comparison of Scopus and WoS journal coverage revealed relatively small number of journals indexed exclusively in WoS (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>), and approximately 97% of WoS journals are also included in Scopus. Thus, Scopus has established a compelling reputation for conducting systematic reviews of the literature (<cite data-doi="10.1080/13683500.2018.1564739">Centobelli and Ndou, 2019</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jbusvent.2021.106092">Anand et al , 2021a</cite>).</note>

The source of this review's database was the Scopus index. According to Mongeon and Paul-Hus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[39]</cite>, Scopus has a better coverage of journals than the Web of Science (WOS) in management subjects, which made it a suitable choice for this review of research on sustainable entrepreneurship <cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">[40]</cite>.

Web of Science (WoS) is considered neutral, representative, and objective data set for literature review. We adopt a similar methodology to that of <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.resconrec.2018.08.004">Maditati et al (2018)</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> and <cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">Falagas et al (2008)</cite>. Rather than simply using the existing methods of data analysis (extracting most locally cited papers and recent trending papers from 2015 to 2018), this study examines the most impactful journals and articles by adopting the techniques of <cite data-doi="10.1108/imr-10-2018-0280">Paul and Rosado-Serrano (2019)</cite>, which consist of analyzing the number of citations, total publications and the H-index.

Therefore, it is necessary to determine whether the candidate topic is a good idea or We included papers in major journals in WoS relatively quickly after publication, but there might be a delay of approximately six months for almost all journals and some research areas may not be reflected in WoS sufficiently quickly, which may delay the identification of research trends. Until the birth of Scopus and Google Scholar in 2004, WoS was the only tool for citation analysis [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 79 </cite> ]. Even today, WoS is known to have a longer record period than Scopus and is one of the most effective databases in the field of history.

A total of 250 sample papers were carefully collected in full-text version from the Web of Science, Google Scholar, and Scopus databases by searching the keywords "safety performance", "safety improvement", and "construction worker safety". The combination of using three common databases can reduce the research bias and improve the reliability of the collected data <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[22]</cite>. Sample size was set at 250 papers to ensure the unbiasedness and reliability of the systematic review of the literature <cite data-doi="10.1080/08874417.2013.11645667">[23]</cite>.

Scopus was chosen because it employs a consistent standard in selecting documents for inclusion in its index. Moreover it features a wider range of documents than the Web of Science for reviews of research in education and the social sciences <cite data-doi="10.3390/su11082401">[27,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">38]</cite>. Finally, it offers more sophisticated capabilities for the export of bibliographic data than Google Scholar.

Its field also has limitations when favor natural sciences and engineering, that represents 43% of the documents, and biomedical research with 27%, compared to 21% of social sciences and 9% of arts and humanities, still underrepresented. At the same way, English-language journals are overrepresentation to the detriment of other languages <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[121,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1080/09537325.2020.1865530">122]</cite>. Therefore, future works must be conducted in order to investigate other databases such as Scopus, PubMed, Science Direct, etc.

It is well documented that WoS (and other major research databases) cover Englishlanguage publications most comprehensively. The output of countries where many researchers publish in other languages is thus easily underestimated <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-011-0382-1">Van Raan et al, 2011)</cite>.

Scopus is the largest abstract and citation database, indexing many serial and non-serial publications and millions of conference papers, including the majority of the most important journals in the field of operations management research as listed in <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jom.2006.09.002">Theoharakis et al (2007)</cite>, <cite data-doi="10.1287/inte.1050.0149">Olson (2005)</cite> and <cite data-doi="10.1016/s0272-6963(00)00060-7">Barman, Hanna, and LaForge (2001)</cite>. It is also one of the most common sources to conduct bibliometric analyses and the most complete one in the engineering field <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>.

However, the low data quality found in Google Scholar raises questions about its suitability for research evaluation” (p. 1). <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">42</cite> As our article is not a literature review but a case study drawing on extant literature, combined with the fact that Scopus has a much larger journal coverage compared to Web of Science, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">42</cite>,<cite data-doi="10.1016/j.outlook.2017.03.004">43</cite> we limited our literature search to Scopus. Figure 1 illustrates the literature selection strategy.

Bibliometric researches are used to compare researches in many areas <cite data-doi="10.15612/bd.2015.499">(Besimoğlu, 2015)</cite>, to evaluate and to follow scientific processes <cite data-doi="10.1023/a:1023619503005">(Gmür, 2003;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.24840/2183-0606_003.002_0010">Santos, 2015;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1207/s15366359mea0301_7">Van Raan, 2005)</cite>. Doing investigations with bibliometric researches serve to identify the co-citation methods that reveal the relationship between documents and the quality and quantity of resources with citation analyzes to examine the development of a research topic <cite data-doi="10.1023/b:scie.0000006878.83104.61">(Tsay, Xu & Wu, 2003;</cite><cite data-doi="10.7763/ijiet.2016.v6.668">Yu, Chang, Yu, 2016)</cite>.

We searched the Web of Science, Scopus and ERIC as these are accepted to be the most relevant databases for peer-reviewed resources in the field of educational technology <cite data-doi="10.14742/ajet.5477">(Bedenlier et al, 2020;</cite><cite data-doi="10.3390/su12177053">Ramirez-Montoya, 2020)</cite>. Whereas Web of Science Core Collection and Scopus ensure interdisciplinary and broad geographical coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>, ERIC focuses on educational science and, therefore, especially on OER.

To reflect the international discourse as best as possible only publications in the English language were considered. Only journal articles were included in the systematic mapping, as this publication type is the main focus in the selected databases <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Other document types, such as book chapters and conference papers, are not comprehensively represented in the databases and were thus excluded.

Most bibliometric analyses tend to use three data sources, namely Thomson Reuters’ WoS, Google Scholars, and Elsevier’s Scopus (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing and Alakangas, 2016</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). After considering the strengths and weaknesses of each data source, we selected the WoS database for several reasons.

Third, its citations are more widely covered in WoS (<cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.23408">Leydesdorff and Bornmann, 2016</cite>). Fourth, several authors have mentioned that Google Scholar offers low accuracy for citation analysis (<cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">Falagas et al , 2008</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). Finally, WoS provides precise information to identify the most frequently cited sources and is the primary data source for bibliometric analysis (<cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ijhm.2015.10.007">García-Lillo et al , 2016</cite>).

First, the data was only collected from the WOS Core Collection, and there may be an issue regarding incomplete publications in the other databases. Future research can utilize WOS and Scopus as research databases to ensure adequate coverage of published papers (Mongeon and Paul-Hus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ; Ranjbari et al <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jclepro.2021.126660"> 2021b </cite> ). Second, other informative analysis tools could be considered to conduct an in-depth analysis of this research dataset in the future.

Clarivate Analytics' Web of Science (WoS) and Elsevier's Scopus databases are synonymous with data on international research, and considered as the two most trusted or authoritative sources of bibliometric data for peer-reviewed global research knowledge across disciplines <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">Archambault et al 2009;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2009.04.001">Alonso et al 2009;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing and Alakangas 2016;</cite>Ràfols et al 2016;<cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">Chadegani et al 2013)</cite>. They are both also used widely for the purposes of researcher evaluation and promotion, institutional impact (for example the role of WoS in the UK Research Excellence Framework 2021 40 ), and international league tables (Bibliographic data from Scopus represents more than 36% of assessment criteria in the THE rankings 41 ).

On the other hand, Scopus is the world's largest database service, providing over 25,100 source titles <cite data-doi="10.1186/1478-4505-9-1">[48]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[49]</cite>[50]. In particular, in the Biomedical Research field and Social Sciences field, the coverage of Scopus is wider than that of Web of Science, with many exclusive journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[49]</cite>. Scopus, widely used to create datasets for systematic reviews of research is also the largest abstract and citation database of peer-reviewed literature, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. It is a typical online academic database that has a great impact on academic literature due to its access to a wide range of journals and sources in all kinds of knowledge areas <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00019">(Baas et al 2020)</cite>.

Compounded with the previous issue, there is the fact that Web of Science and Scopus, the most widely used selective databases for bibliometric analyses, are known to have poor coverage of areas in which research often has a local projection such as the Social Sciences and Humanities <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>, as well as a bias against non-English publications <cite data-doi="10.1093/reseval/rvy001">(Chavarro, Ràfols, & Tang, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1023/a:1010549719484">van Leeuwen, Moed, Tijssen, Visser, & Van Raan, 2001)</cite>. This goes against the principle of protecting "excellence in locally relevant research" in the Leiden Manifesto <cite data-doi="10.1038/520429a">(Hicks, Wouters, Waltman, de Rijcke, & Rafols, 2015)</cite>.

It is known that database selection affects the value that a bibliometric indicator takes for a given unit of analysis <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-006-0115-z">(Archambault, Vignola-Gagné, Côté, Larivière, & Gingrasb, 2006;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-008-0216-y">Bar-Ilan, 2008;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.20817">Frandsen & Nicolaisen, 2008;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.20677">Meho & Yang, 2007;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). These differences are sometimes caused by diametrically opposed approaches to document indexing: indexing based on journal selection (Web of Science, Scopus), or inclusive indexing based on automated web crawling of individual academic documents (Google Scholar, Microsoft Academic, and other academic search engines).

The use of various bibliographic databases is a good practice in Systematic Literature Reviews carried out in the Operations Management area, which could reduce the publication bias (<cite data-doi="10.1080/09537287.2015.1129464">Thomé et al , 2016</cite>).

We acknowledge that we used a single search engine to obtain our results, and we therefore could have missed papers on ALAN that were published in highly specialized or local journals, articles that were not in English and/or publications that would be considered grey literature (e.g. government reports, theses; Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>). In the Life Sciences, we anticipate this could lead to a loss of up to 7%–8% of journal articles (Vieira & Gomes, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">2009</cite>).

This possibility is particularly relevant given widely documented sociocultural variation in emotion-related processes (e.g., <cite data-doi="10.1037/emo0000390">Boiger et al, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1177/0963721417746794">Gendron et al, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1177/1745691619849591">Niedenthal et al, 2019;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1037/pspp0000072">Tamir et al, 2016)</cite> and must be dealt with to ensure the generalizability of our proposed framework. The databases we used may have likewise limited our results (e.g., <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Unlike conventional bibliometric databases, citations are more focused towards social sciences, economics and environmental sciences than to biological and physical sciences, a feature that suggests novel value in the content in terms of analytical potential. The balance of content by region broadly follows that of other bibliometric databases, namely it is dominated by North America and Europe, but the representation of local language documents is much higher than in scholarly publishing where English dominates <cite data-doi="10.3389/fcomm.2020.00031">(Márquez & Porras, 2020;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The traditional bibliometric databases, namely the Web of Science (Clarivate), Scopus (Elsevier), Dimensions (Digital Science), Microsoft Academic (Microsoft), and Google Scholar (Google), have been extensively evaluated <cite data-doi="10.2478/jdis-2019-0001">(Aksnes & Sivertsen, 2019;</cite><cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">Chadegani et al, 2013;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">Falagas et al, 2008;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing & Alakangas, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00112">Visser et al, 2021)</cite>, particularly in terms of cited references <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03690-4">(Martín-Martín et al, 2021)</cite>, subject coverage <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.09.002">(Martín-Martín et al, 2018)</cite>, comparability of citation metrics <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.03.006">(Thelwall, 2018)</cite>, journal coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-021-03948-5">Singh et al, 2021)</cite>, classification systems <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.02.003">(Wang & Waltman, 2016)</cite>, accuracy of reference linking <cite data-doi="10.1038/483036d">(Alcaraz & Morais, 2012;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.23590">Olensky et al, 2016)</cite>, duplication <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2015.05.002">(Valderrama-Zurián et al, 2015)</cite>, suitability for application with national and institutional aggregations <cite data-doi="10.3389/frma.2020.593494">(Guerrero-Bote et al, 2021)</cite>, language coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z">(Vera-Baceta et al, 2019)</cite>, regional bias <cite data-doi="10.31235/osf.io/3kf9d">(Rafols et al, 2020;</cite><cite data-doi="10.3897/ese.2020.e51987">Tennant, 2020)</cite>, and predatory publishing <cite data-doi="10.3390/publications8020017">(Björk et al, 2020;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1177/0961000618784159">Demir, 2020)</cite>. Despite the contributions of these articles, IS has not been studied comprehensively through a bibliometric analysis because previous analyses have focused on particular aspects of symbiosis or because the employed search keywords have been limited in scope. Methodological choices such as the selection of search keywords and databases could largely influence the results of such studies <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Building on work begun by <cite data-doi="10.1007/978-3-319-20571-7_5">Chertow and Park (2016)</cite>, we aimed to fill these gaps in knowledge by first conducting an expansive bibliometric analysis of articles on IS using the conventional library databases, WoS and Scopus, to investigate: (1) what is the intellectual structure of the domain of IS; and (2) how have frameworks, concepts, and theories on IS advanced through the year 2018?

Due to the relevance to the area and availability of indexed journals, the ISI, Science Direct, Emerald, Willey, and Scopus databases were searched <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>, considering only papers published in peer-reviewed journals. Peer-reviewed journal articles tend to demonstrate a more consistent degree of quality than other types of documents <cite data-doi="10.3390/su11123428">(Zheng & Kouwenberg, 2019)</cite>.

Bibliometrics allow for a systematic examination of the topical content, impact, and geographical distribution of research output in many academic disciplines <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1645-z">(Ellegaard & Wallin, 2015)</cite>. Bibliometric analyses most commonly rely on information from Web of Science (WoS), maintained by Clarivate Analytics (formerly a part of Thomson Reuters), and Scopus, Elsevier's abstract and citation database <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The subscription bibliographic databases, Web of Science Core Collection (WoS CC) and Scopus, consist of manually curated lists of publications judged by panelists to be of the highest quality as determined by their respective decision-making bodies (see Appendix A in Supporting Information S1 for more detail on the indexing process of publications).

Moreover, other researchers <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03387-8">(Zhu and Liu, 2020)</cite> believe there is no concrete evidence on which index is better.

Some researchers argue that Scopus is a good alternative for WoS for bibliometric analysis <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">(Vieira and Gomes, 2009)</cite> as it was designed for bibliographic searches and citation data extraction (Meho and Yang, 2007a, b). In addition, Scopus has a broader coverage of social sciences research than WoS <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The broader coverage of journals in Scopus results in the broad coverage of citations, too.

The data analyzed in this work have been obtained mainly from the databases Scopus and, to a lesser extent, the Web of Science (WoS). Both bibliographic databases are the main sources of information used in bibliometric studies <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[40,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.09.002">41]</cite> because of the large number of documents they contain. It is also less biased by data inconsistencies, lack of transparency and manipulation in citation counts than Google Scholar (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>).
