As interest in corporate governance has evolved mainly since the late 1990s, the SCOPUS index, published by Elsevier, was considered most suitable for the purposes of this review. This conclusion is supported by other management scholars <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[33]</cite>.

Third, by not incorporating articles that have not yet been cited, the study may not reflect the very latest trends in the field (e.g., monetization and business models, big data and learning flexibility, sustainability). Fourth, English, as the language for publications, is over-represented in the WOS and Scopus databases, in the same way that certain scientific fields are more prevalent than others; social sciences, as well as arts and humanities, for example, may be underrepresented <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The results of this study are also affected by the rapid evolution of scientific literature on MOOCs in recent years.

The bibliographic search was performed using the SCOPUS database, as it is a large, multidisciplinary database that includes MEDLINE and focuses on natural sciences and biomedical research [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 32 </cite> ]. As expected, the number of publications focusing on each group (swine, human, mouse and ferret) decreased as the criteria increased its restrictiveness ( Figure 1 ).

This might have reduced the variety of searchable literature. However, bibliographic studies <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">(Harzing and Alakangas, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite> on the coverage of Scopus and Web of Science suggest that it is one of the broadest and the most comprehensive searchable digital libraries. Therefore, we think that the chance of missing a study is relatively low.

Assessing these two databases, it was found that WoS has a record of 16,957 journals and Scopus has a record of 34,274 journal titles <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[4]</cite>. Contrasting the lists of WoS and Scopus journals having as criteria the ISSN, the title, and identifying active journals and eliminating duplicates, or the same journal with an electronic ISSN, and another printed version, or non-active journals, the corresponding list of WoS is 13,605 journals and Scopus is 21,900 journal titles (1,800 in open access) from more than 5,000 international editors and 55 million records [2,<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">4]</cite>. Scopus is the largest database of bibliographic references with abstracts and citations of peer-reviewed scientific literature.

Subsequently, observations with missing data were eliminated, leaving 72,650 unique titles. This number is reliable since it approximates the result in Mongeon and Paul-Hus's study which reaches 70,644 <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

As a limitation of our research, it should be noted that our results are restricted in some directions. The first limitation comes from limitations of database that we used because all our results are retrieved from WoS, but a research [<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">84</cite>] shows that there is a high overlap between WoS and Scopus as another possible option for bibliometric study in natural science and Engineering. Also using Google Scholar as a source for bibliometrics involves issues such as data validity and ease of manipulation of citation data [<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">84</cite>].

The articles were taken from Scopus rather than WoS because of its greater coverage of non-English sources <cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">(Falagas et al 2008;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon, & Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>, which is important for the Arts and Humanities because these often publish in local languages. Thus, a Web of Science dataset would be likely to overrepresent articles from English-speaking nations more than Scopus.

Various research studies have assessed the superposition between both, concluding that they are similar when the coverage since 1996 is restricted (Scopus coverage) [<cite data-doi="10.3390/publications5040025">28</cite>,<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-010-0185-9">29</cite>]. Regarding the journals reported in the two large scientific databases such as Web of Science (WoS) and Scopus, a comparative analysis shows that the range of journals in WoS (13,605 journals) is smaller than that of Scopus (20,346 journals) [<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">30</cite>], and the relationships between the results obtained with both databases for the number of articles and the number of citations obtained by countries, as well as for their rankings, are extremely strong (R 2 ≈ 0.99) [<cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">31</cite>]. Therefore, only Scopus data have been used.

In accordance with the goal of the present study, a systematic search was carried out in WoS Core Collection database, which includes high quality scientific and scholarly research in over 250 science, social sciences, and humanities disciplines. WoS is an authoritative source for researchers and one of the main sources for citation data <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[44]</cite>, an important source of scientific documentation for bibliometric analysis <cite data-doi="10.3390/su11216136">[22]</cite>. In our search strategy, we followed PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) guidelines for conducting reviews of research <cite data-doi="10.1371/journal.pmed.1000097">[45]</cite>.

Among them are Web of Science (WoS), Scopus, and Google Scholar. WoS and Scopus provide subscription-based access to databases of articles published in journals, books, and conference proceedings (see <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-010-0202-z">[34]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.23590">[35]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.23437">[36]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2015.11.008">[37]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2015.05.002">[38]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[39]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z">[40]</cite> for their coverage and accuracy). Google Scholar is primarily a free search engine for scholarly literature that indexes theses, preprints, and technical reports in addition to journals, books, and conference proceedings (see <cite data-doi="10.1007/978-3-030-02511-3_4">[41,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1614-6">42]</cite> for its coverage and quality).

Initially, two databases were considered: Web of Science (WoS) and Scopus. Despite the overlapping issues, both were used, as they are considered the best international sources for multidisciplinary investigations in transport <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[64]</cite>[65]<cite data-doi="10.1016/j.scs.2019.101625">[66]</cite>.

An internal debate among the authors also highlighted the question of whether the use of Elsevier's Scopus bibliographic database, instead of Thomson Reuters' Web of Science (WoF), or both, may have contributed to bias in the geographical distribution of the GASEMT records. The decision to use Scopus in this analysis was based on the information available in the literature indicating that Scopus has greater coverage of specific subjects in Earth and Atmospheric Sciences and a larger match with compared to WoF(Barnett and Lascar, 2012;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. A recent Scopus and WoS query (17.03.2020) searching `soil erosion models` in the title, abstract, and keywords resulted in 13,474 and 12,972 articles potentially reporting applications of soil erosion modelling, respectively.

An earlier study indicated that the journal coverage is higher in Scopus than in Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">[40]</cite>. In addition, numerous research articles have suggested the advantages of using Scopus to implement a bibliometric analysis <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[41,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.tele.2017.10.010">42]</cite>. Therefore, the Scopus database was selected.

Scholarly communication is a global phenomenon, with English as a dominant language of scientific publications and conference presentations. The analysis of language coverage for journals indexed in two major citation databases, Web of Science and Scopus, demonstrates that English is overwhelmingly represented in both databases and across disciplines (Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"></cite>). The dominance of English in scholarly discourse is advantageous for native speakers of English.

This version of Scopus determined open access status by whether a journal was registered in DOAJ or ROAD as of April 2017. Note that Scopus does not index every scholarly journal ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2015 </cite> ), which is one reason why 30.5% of articles (24,853,345 DOIs) were not attributable to a journal.

Moreover, both databases are not only used as reference in a large number of bibliometric studies (cf. <cite data-doi="10.1080/16184742.2013.838283">Ciomaga, 2013)</cite>, but also, are the main sources for citation data <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

Nowadays, English remains the most used language in the web, used by 25.2 % of Internet users worldwide, followed by Chinese that counts for the 19.3% of the Internet users [8]. In addition, in a study by Mongeon and Paul-Hus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[25]</cite> using Web of Science and Elsevier's Scopus, it is suggested that journals written in the English language are overrepresented to the disadvantage of other languages. This is indicative of the fact that the authors are writing in the English language, even when it is not their mother tongue.

Unfortunately, this journal evaluation system fails as well because it relies uncritically on JCR and Scopus as whitelists and does not specify the term ‘fast peer review’. Moreover, the authors' claim that a journal not indexed in the International Academy of Nursing Editors or Scimago Journal & Country Rank (SJR) could be predatory ignores the fact that several quality journals are not indexed in either of these databases – SJR is based on the content of Scopus, which does not include many respected journals indexed in Web of Science (Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"></cite>).

<note n="2" place="foot" xmlns:="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">https ://webof knowl edge.com/.3 Since 2004, two other tools are available (Scopus and Google Scholar). Each of the three available databases provides sufficient stability of coverage to be used for detailed cross-disciplinary comparisons (Harzing and Alakangas 2016), and each has its relative strengths and weaknesses<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. I have chosen the WoS as the main source because of its large coverage of journals and its compatibility with other software tools used in this article.</note>

The databases used were Scopus (Elsevier) and WOS (Web of Science, Clarivate Analytics). The reason for selecting them was their wide coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. In an initial step, we used the keywords 'sex chromosome', and later added 'plant', but the search results were too unspecific, and in most cases, publications with sex chromosomes in animals were retrieved.

Lastly, the variety of publication venues, languages, scholarly communities in the arts and humanities is broader, making reference practices and styles less uniform. For these and other reasons, the scholarly literature from the arts and humanities is still not well indexed <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>) nor studied <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.22835">(Ardanuy, 2013)</cite> using citation data.

Web of Science (WoS) and Scopus are the most important databases of scientific literature. However, there are works comparing them and concluding that using Scopus, the largest database of peer-reviewed scientific articles in the world, is the best option <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[63]</cite>. Studies determine that, while 54% of Scopus titles are indexed in WoS <cite data-doi="10.1108/14684520810865958">[64]</cite>, 84% of WoS titles are also indexed in Scopus.

The use of complementary search to Scopus and WoS contributed to a more accurate assessment. Moreover, types of citing documents significantly differed between disciplines, suggesting that a broad range of academic non-journal publications not be indexed in WoS but are accessible through others database <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Hus, 2016)</cite>. Finally, the most cited articles on references of papers also were analysed and, if considered adherent with the inclusion/exclusion criteria, were included in analyses.

This research has some limitations. The three journal citation databases favour English-language journals <cite data-doi="10.1087/20110408">(Didegah & Gazni, 2011;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.22873">Tang & Hu, 2013)</cite>. This may underestimate the use of non-English languages in scholarly communication since non-indexation does not mean that the journals do not exist or are not of local or regional importance.

According to Mongeon and Paul-Hus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[9]</cite>, there were exactly 13,605 journals in WoS in 2014. With about 22,800 serial titles, 20,346 of which are journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[9]</cite>, Scopus is more inclusive. Compared to Ulrich's with around 63,013 active academic journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[9]</cite>, both databases cover only minor parts of the entire scientific production.

We chose a database providing statistical functions, Scopus ® , owned by Elsevier ® which offers a better coverage of the humanities, social sciences, and public health than WoS ® <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(14)</cite>.

The database is highly comprehensive, but might not cover all institutional entrepreneurship literature. Therefore, future studies might also use other databases such as Scopus or Google Scholar <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">(Archambault et al 2009;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing and Alakangas 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>.

Microsoft Academic only found statistically significantly more citations than Scopus for older dissertations published during 2009-2012 in Social Sciences, Business and Management, and Education, suggesting that it may have better coverage of social science publications than Scopus (Figures 6-7). This would reflect the incomplete coverage of social sciences journals by Scopus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

3 Counting affiliations from published articles has the advantage of being available at a large scale and with high coverage (as opposed to, for example, CVs or university websites). We derive all data from Scopus which has three important advantages over other indexing systems: comprehensive coverage of scientific articles <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>, disambiguation of authors and their affiliations along with the assignment of unique Author IDs, and the availability of additional information on institution addresses (e.g., country and organization type).

Journal of Data and Information Science Factors Influencing Cities' Publishing Efficiency http://www.jdis.org https://www.degruyter.com/view/j/jdis journals are still significantly overrepresented <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2014.09.003">(Li et al 2014;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. According to <cite data-doi="10.1068/a3769">Paasi (2005)</cite>, 'Anglo-American journals dominate the publishing space in science', and the international journal publication space is 'particularly limited to the English-speaking countries'.

Water 2019, 11, x FOR PEER REVIEW 5 of 16 <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[38]</cite> (p. 2013) state that "the results of bibliometric analyses may vary depending on the database used". Before the emergence of Scopus (Elsevier) in 2004, and for more than 40 years, WoS (Thomson Reuters) was the only bibliographic database capable of providing statistics based on bibliometric indicators.

We are aware that there has been much discussion about which academic search database offers the least error-prone results and the highest coverage for knowledge discovery and researchers' assessment, e.g., <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">[23]</cite>- [26]. Later in Section 4, we report how Scopus was found to be the most reliable [26] and comprehensive <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[25]</cite> academic search engine that is compatible with our aims. Scopus also offers advanced search engine features such as finding variant spellings.

The end of the cold war appears to have also increased collaboration levels between FRG researchers and Eastern countries, especially in NSE. The difference between collaboration with the East and the West may, however, be overestimated by the larger number of papers published by Western countries and the higher coverage of journals in English in the Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-006-0115-z">(Archambault et al, 2006;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The difference between the pre-and post-reunification periods reflects not only a shift in collaboration practices, but also a higher "survival" rate of GDR researchers who already collaborated with the West before the reunification.

Impressively, Sci-Hub’s coverage of the closed articles in the Web of Science collection was 97.8%. This remarkable coverage likely reflects that these articles were published from 2009–2015 and classified as citable items by Web of Science, which is selective when indexing journals ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2015 </cite> ). Note that PennText does not have complete coverage of bronze, hybrid, and gold articles, which should be the case were all metadata systems perfect.

It is important to emphasize that the end of a publishing career does not always imply an end of an academic career; authors who stopped publishing often retain teaching or administrative duties, or conduct productive research in industry or governmental positions, with less pressure to communicate their findings through research publications. Scientific publications represent only one of the possible academic outputs; in some academic disciplines books and patents are equally important, and all three of our data sources (WoS, MAG and DBLP) tend to overrepresent STEM and English language publications <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[56]</cite>, thereby possibly biasing our analysis. Furthermore, our bibliometric approach can draw deep insight into the large-scale statistical patterns reflecting gender differences, yet we cannot observe and test potential variation in the organizational context and resources available to individual researchers [13,<cite data-doi="10.1038/387341a0">57]</cite>.

Finally, in the fourth step, there is the basis of the data used to measure research contribution. It is well known that publication databases vary in coverage of subject fields and languages <cite data-doi="10.2478/jdis-2019-0001">(Aksnes & Sivertsen, 2019;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z">Vera-Baceta, Thelwall, & Kousha, 2019)</cite>, which will further affect any rankings and evaluations.

Our searches were carried out using the search field topic, which searches in title, abstract, author keywords, and Keywords Plus® (plus publication channel name for part of SDG 14). WoS does not, however, cover all academic fields equally; natural sciences, technology, medicine, and health are well indexed, while the social sciences and particularly the arts and humanities are less well covered, in part due to its focus on articles <cite data-doi="10.2478/jdis-2019-0001">(Aksnes & Sivertsen, 2019;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. We ran two analyses to estimate how well Nordic or Norwegian publications relevant to SDG 1 and SDG 3 would be covered, which suggested a rate of ≥93% for SDG 3 and ≥79% for SDG 1 (Supplementary Material 1).

In addition, online publications can introduce errors, which can double count the same publication or reduce the time it takes for a study to be published after being accepted, possibly distorting the influence on the citation of the study [ <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.07.003"> 16 </cite> ]. Another issue is related to the limited range of journals included in the WoS database [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 17 </cite> ]. From this perspective, it is acknowledged that there may have been errors in the selection and analysis of literature.

That is why this term was chosen. The ISI WoS and Scopus are the databases of scientific articles considered as key for the accomplishment of bibliographic revision, since they gather a set of journals from different publishers, and publications from national and international literature <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Three steps were taken for the bibliometric analysis, according to what was established in the study by Mesquita et al (2015): choosing the database and the collection criteria, data collection and data representation and analysis.

The latter covers works published since 1966, indexing 12,850 journals in fields such as physical sciences, health sciences, life sciences, and of course, social sciences <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">(Archambault et al, 2009;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">Falagas et al, 2008)</cite>. The two databases have been widely adopted in prior academic research <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11365-015-0356-5">(Liñán & Fayolle, 2015;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1108/ijchm-07-2017-0461">Mariani et al, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.techfore.2019.119752">Mariani & Borghi, 2019;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1177/1094428114562629">Zupic & Čater, 2015)</cite>, and are considered the most comprehensive sources of studies in the social sciences <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">Vieira & Gomes, 2009)</cite>. The data for this study were collected in January 2021, with the search limited to articles published until 2020.

Interestingly, <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">Archambault, Campbell, et al (2009)</cite> also showed that the rankings of countries by number of papers and citations were highly correlated between results extracted separately from WoS and Scopus. <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> found that the journal coverages of both WoS and Scopus were biased toward Natural Sciences, Engineering and Biomedical Research. More importantly, their overall coverages differed significantly.

Scopus generally includes more articles as Web of Science, see e.g. <cite data-doi="10.1080/15424065.2010.505518">Li, Burnham, Lemley, and Britton (2010)</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite>, but as WoS it is selective. For further readings on this we refer to <cite data-doi="10.2478/jdis-2019-0001">Aksnes and Sivertsen (2019)</cite>.

Using a single database increases the degree of transparency and facilitates replicability. Furthermore, Scopus indexes a large number of journals within the article's topic (IT and BA), when compared with other international databases <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Table 1 shows the selected keywords, which cover a broad scope in the areas of BA and IT.

This is a simplification because the researcher might move abroad afterwards but stop researching or publish different types of document. The choice of Scopus-indexed publications is also for pragmatic reasons because it is not possible to get useful citation data from all relevant national publications, despite the relatively wide coverage of Scopus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. For example, Chinese researchers may produce excellent Chinese-language publications indexed in the Chinese Science Citation Index (now in the Web of Science, as is the Russian Science Citation Index, SciELO (including Spain) and the Korean Journal Index).

Despite its known errors and limitations, which are consequence of its automated approach to document indexing <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.23056">(Delgado López-Cózar, Robinson-García, & Torres-Salinas, 2014;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1108/14684521011024191">Jacsó, 2010)</cite>, GS has been shown to be reliable and to have good coverage of disciplines and languages, especially in the Humanities and Social Sciences, where WoS and Scopus are known to be weak <cite data-doi="10.1093/reseval/rvy001">(Chavarro, Ràfols, & Tang, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1023/a:1010549719484">van Leeuwen, Moed, Tijssen, Visser, & Van Raan, 2001)</cite>. Analyses of the coverage of GS, WoS, and Scopus across disciplines have compared the numbers of publications indexed or their average citation counts for samples of documents, authors, or journals, finding that GS consistently returned higher numbers of publications and citations <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-013-0975-y">(Harzing, 2013;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing & Alakangas, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-010-0270-0">Mingers & Lipitakis, 2010;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1093/reseval/rvv049">Prins, Costas, van Leeuwen, & Wouters, 2016)</cite>.

Many of them are published by large commercial publishing houses <cite data-doi="10.1371/journal.pone.0127502">(Larivière et al, 2015)</cite> and indexed in large international databases like Web of Science (WoS) or Scopus. It has been observed that these databases contain an overrepresentation of English-language journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-006-0115-z">(Archambault et al, 2006;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

The important feature of these databases is that they include all article types and index all authors, institutional addresses, and bibliographic references for each article <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[52]</cite>. Archambault et al <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">[53]</cite> have shown a high correlation between the number of papers and the number of citations received by country calculated with WoS and with Scopus, and thus concluded that both databases are suitable tool for scientometric analyses.

Archambault et al <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">[53]</cite> have shown a high correlation between the number of papers and the number of citations received by country calculated with WoS and with Scopus, and thus concluded that both databases are suitable tool for scientometric analyses. The WoS has traditionally been the main source of scientific evaluation for its high quality and long history coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s10490-018-9597-5">[23]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ibusrev.2017.02.007">[24]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ibusrev.2019.101660">[25]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">52,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">53]</cite>. However, Scopus has become a good alternative to the WoS because it has been designed for both literature search and citation analysis <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.20677">[54,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">55]</cite> and has greater coverage of exclusive journals compared to the WoS, particularly suitable for emerging topics <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[52,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11365-017-0487-y">56]</cite>.

For this purpose, the search for terms to carry out the study in the field of CE and agriculture, as well as the downloading of data and delimitation of variables were supported by Scopus. Among the various tools available, this database was chosen for its easy access as well as its download utilities <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[33]</cite>.

The WoS has traditionally been the main source of scientific evaluation for its high quality and long history coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s10490-018-9597-5">[23]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ibusrev.2017.02.007">[24]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.ibusrev.2019.101660">[25]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">52,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">53]</cite>. However, Scopus has become a good alternative to the WoS because it has been designed for both literature search and citation analysis <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.20677">[54,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">55]</cite> and has greater coverage of exclusive journals compared to the WoS, particularly suitable for emerging topics <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[52,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11365-017-0487-y">56]</cite>. Thus, we combined both databases to achieve the best coverage in both quality and wideness.

• Web of Science (Wos): the Web of Science database hosted by the competence centre for bibliometrics is used to determine the publication output for all German universities. Although WoS is not exhaustive, and it is known for a selective coverage and for various biases <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[25,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1023/a:1010549719484">26]</cite>, the advantage of this version of the database is that it is enriched with disambiguated institutional addresses for German institutions [27,28]. This allows us to precisely identify the publication output of research institutions in that source.

The publications are the result of collaboration both within India and on the international scene. Our results indicate that the studies on COVID-19 are published by institutions worldwide as also reported by <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[63]</cite>, who studied bibliometric features on the COVID-19 globally. There are many publications in India, which had a rapidly increasing rate of publication after disease emerged in the country, in a pattern similar to that reported by <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jobb.2020.12.002">[64]</cite>.

Bibliometric indicators were applied to evaluate bibliographic data, and these include the total number of authors and articles, citations, institutions and countries. Moreover, the documents used for analysis were obtained from the largest database of multidisciplinary peer-reviewed literature -Scopus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. This database is popular and often used to obtain quantitative analyzes (Dur an-S anchez et al, 2019) due to the availability of a wider range of high-quality peer-reviewed articles in business and management compared to Google Scholar or others <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jbusres.2020.06.057">(Verma and Gustafsson, 2020)</cite>.

You should gather publications from multiple (at least two) databases because overlaps between published databases can range from around 50% to as low as 11% (Bar‐Ilan, <cite data-doi="10.3389/frma.2018.00006">2018</cite>; Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>). For researchers who have limited access to the required databases, they might need to collaborate with others who do have access or supplement their search using other search methods.

We base our search on the Scopus citation database. According to Mongeon and Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">42</cite> most bibliometric analyses are based on Thomson Reuters' Web of Science (WoS) and Elsevier's Scopus. Furthermore, "WoS had been the sole tool for citations analysis until the creation of Scopus and Google Scholar in 2004.

This study was conducted using secondary data from Scopus website. Earlier studies have expressed the importance of Scopus database and claimed it to be better than Web of Science due to its comprehensiveness (<cite data-doi="10.1016/j.tele.2017.10.010">Montoya et al , 2018</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). As the study aims to look at publications undertaken in the area of Business and Management, Scopus website was accessed and advanced filters were used to draw relevant research papers.

<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1645-z">[14]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.09.002">[15]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.acalib.2012.08.002">[16]</cite> Google Scholar provides free access to scholarly documents of all types, which makes it questioned due to sporadic coverage. <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">17</cite> WoS and Scopus are the most extensive databases in different scientific fields, used for searching the literature. <cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">18</cite> Therefore, in this research SCOPUS and WoS databases are compared against the coverage of "Exosome" research and the best one is selected for the study.

Scopus was chosen in preference to the Web of Science for more comprehensive coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite> and in preference to Dimensions <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2018.03.006">(Thelwall, 2018a)</cite>, Google Scholar <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">(Harzing & Alakangas, 2016)</cite> and Microsoft Academic <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-017-2454-3">(Harzing & Alakangas, 2017)</cite> due to having a standard classification scheme that is known to be reasonably consistent <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.23734">(Klavans & Boyack, 2017)</cite> and substantial long term coverage. Scopus records from 1996 to 2013 were downloaded in late 2018, and Scopus records from 2014 to 2019 were downloaded in early 2020 so every citation count used is based on at least three full years of citations.

Because most researchers do not have the possibility to retrieve large amounts of data from data sources such as Scopus and WoS, bibliographic data sources are typically compared in small-scale case studies, focusing for instance on documents in a specific research field or on a small number of researchers and the documents they have authored (e.g., <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03114-y">Harzing, 2019)</cite>. A large-scale comparison of Scopus and WoS was presented by <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite>, but this comparison was performed at the level of journals rather than individual documents. Recently, Huang et al (in press) reported a document-level comparison of Scopus, WoS, and Microsoft Academic based on a fairly large amount of data (i.e., documents published by 15 universities).

As one of the objectives of this research is to identify a major hierarchical decision-making framework that supports the adoption of Industry 4.0 applications in configuring circular supply networks, we synthesised knowledge from the existing literature. To ensure scientific integrity, we taxonomised articles retrieved from the Scopus s R and Web of Science s R databases as these catalogue a broad range of peer-reviewed journals in the Natural Sciences and Engineering fields <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. To identify peer-reviewed articles jointly investigating Circular Economy and Industry 4.0, we performed Boolean searches using appropriate keywords.

If the mouse cursor is positioned on top of one of the nodes, the number of papers that are related to it is displayed. Figure A3 shows an example corresponding to the article that had the highest number of interactions and was cited the most times: Tiwari et al <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[52]</cite>. Oddly, this article was not the most cited in general but it was the most cited by the articles on the list, which established an interesting distinction.

The keyword search was conducted using the Scopus database. Scopus has been demonstrated to be a comprehensive and widely accepted database consisting of most of the journals indexed by Web of Science and Google Scholar (G€ olgeci et al, 2021;<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing and Alakangas, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.31235/osf.io/42nkm">Mart ın-Mart ın et al, 2018;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Scopus is also an effective tool for searching literature as it facilitates searching by allowing the use of whole search strings such as "food" and "open innovation" <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.tifs.2019.11.002">(Bouzembrak et al, 2019)</cite>.

The author used the Scopus database because it has a better coverage of journals in different research fields focusing on management and the social sciences <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The search areas were titles, abstracts, and keywords.

There are diverse bibliographic databases used for bibliometric analysis such as Web of Science (WoS), Scopus, Google Scholar, and Microsoft Academic. For this project, we selected WoS since it makes downloading data easy for bibliometric purposes, fits with the scientific coverage of our research area <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[51]</cite>, and offers robust tools for measuring science <cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">[52]</cite>.

To perform data collection in the fields related to design teams and teamwork, the search was conducted in the Scopus and the Web of Science libraries. The reasons for selecting the databases of Scopus and Web of Science are as follows: (1) they have a relatively wide range of coverage in the domain of construction research compared with other databases <cite data-doi="10.1061/(asce)co.1943-7862.0001492">[34]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.autcon.2017.12.002">[35]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2014.07.006">[36]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[37]</cite>; (2) they are a better choice for interdisciplinary research topics <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[37]</cite>; and (3) they have a wide range of coverage on journal publications [38]. The search strategy was the application of the seven following reference topics "design team", "teamwork", "collaboration", "team interaction", "building", "construction", and "problems" combined into twelve search possibilities (I to XII) in the fields "title, abstract and keywords".

We conducted a search in the Web of Science (WoS) and Scopus database, the two main academic collections in the literature <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. In this study, we used Business, Management and Accounting and Economics categories in Scopus and Business, Management, Ethics, Business Finance and Economics in Web of Science.

It is a powerful library that can perform complete bibliometric and scientometric analysis. In recent years, many authors have published database comparisons on different topics to compare the results obtained <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">(Harzing & Alakangas, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.5539/ass.v9n5p18">Chadegani et al, 2013;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">Falagas et al, 2008;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">Archambault et al, 2009;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. Furthermore, it allows to obtain multiple types of graphs; features not common in other libraries.

The choice between the two is not neutral, and it conditions the final results <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2017.08.007">[15]</cite>; differences between these databases are still not completely clear, and they are contested <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.02.007">[54]</cite>. Some authors showed that Scopus has a general broader coverage than WoS [52], <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[55]</cite>. Despite its broader coverage, Scopus presents some issues.

Bibliometric data on publications from Social Sciences and Humanities. We use data from Scopus, a database of scientific publications, most of them written in English <cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">(Falagas et al 2008;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. Our unit of observation is a publication record, which contains the title and abstract of a unique publication.

The search was executed in Scopus database because it was considered as the largest database than others <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.bej.2018.05.002">[4]</cite>. It also offered wide-ranging coverage of the subjects than that of MedLine, Web of Sciences and so on <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.bej.2018.05.002">[4]</cite>, [6], <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[7]</cite>.

The article retrieved from Scopus was compared by the Web of Science (WOS) database to ensure no significant sources were missed. Additionally, as <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> suggested, the Scopus database has broader coverage in every area of research, including the social sciences. In this case, we tested these results by obtaining 21 results on WOS and 527 on Scopus.

One of the most important advantages of WoS, owned by Clarivate Analytics, is that it provides such customized, citation-based research analytics tools as the InCites and Essential Science Indicators platforms. The utilization of WoS for conducting this analysis would be a quite reasonable choice if we did not realize two fundamental problems (at least viewed from the perspective of Hungarian researchers): 1) nearly two-thirds (64 percent) of the publications indexed in WoS are journal articles, and 2) English-language publications are significantly overrepresented in the database <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The latter factor seems to be rather problematic because, due to the heavy language bias of WoS, a more favorable condition is created for natural sciences against social sciences in which a significant proportion of the publications are produced in a non-English language.

First, publications were retrieved only from the WoS database, which limits the generalizability of the findings. Second, WoS provides stronger coverage of Life Sciences, Biomedical Sciences, and Engineering, and includes a disproportionate number of publications in the English language <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. This could partially explain the low number of publications emerging from the Social Sciences, the Arts, and the Humanities, and research conducted in non-English speaking countries in the present study.

Using specialized databases such as PubMed would introduce biases into the search strategy favoring biomedical research disciplines. Still, it is important to note that interdisciplinary databases such as WoS and Scopus discriminate against publications in the Social Sciences and Humanities and publications in languages other than the English language <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>, so the picture provided by WoS is still imperfect. Third, while other databases might provide wider coverage, WoS includes publication and citation information from 1900.

The Scopus index was used for the document search focusing on sustainability and HRM. The Scopus index was specifically selected due to its superior coverage of documents in management fields, as compared with the Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[41]</cite>. Although potentially relevant articles have been published in multiple languages, this review limited eligibility to English language publications.

Our bibliographic databases of choice have been Scopus and Web of Science (WoS). The two databases still represent the primary reference for bibliographic analyses, in particular for the fields of Natural Science and Engineering <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[17]</cite>, which is where the theme of Industry 4.0 lies. Though the coverage of Web of Science is smaller than Scopus, their union provide a comprehensive and authoritative view of what is published on a subject.

relevant databases, search strings and inclusion or exclusion criteria). As regards the data collection strategy, the Scopus database was preferred over Web of Science (WoS), because Scopus includes most of the journals indexed in WoS and has a larger number of exclusive journals than WoS in all fields <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[32]</cite>. Specifically, the Scopus database was selected because it includes over 75 million records and more than 24,600 titles in the areas of science, technology, medicine, social sciences, art and humanities.

Web of Science (Wos): the Web of Science database hosted by the competence centre for bibliometrics 1 is used to determine the publication output for all German universities. Although WoS is not exhaustive and is known for a selective coverage and for various biases <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[27,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1023/a:1010549719484">28]</cite>, the advantage of this version of the database is that it is enriched with disambiguated institutional addresses for German institutions [29,30]. This allows us to precisely identify the publication output of research institutions in that source.

In particular, during this stage we set up the Web of Science search engine in order to obtain only articles that had drought and societally relevant words 1 in the title. Web of Science was selected because it has a large database and is considered among the most trusted and accurate search engines (Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ). Year of publication, language, and type of documents were other basic criteria used to limit the number of articles.

In addition to authors and journals names, the Web of Science database indexes other metadata, including years of publications, keywords, and institutions of authors, as well as different indicators of research impact. Web of Science was chosen for this article because of the quality of its metadata compared to Google Scholar, and of the historical depth of its indexing compared to Scopus (Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>; Sugimoto & Larivière, 2018). Examples of bibliometric studies that used Web of Science carried out on topics similar to those addressed in this article include Dodier (<cite data-doi="10.1002/acp.3498">2019</cite>) analysis of the recovered memory controversy in the 21st century, Plusquellec and Denault (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s10919-018-0280-9">2018</cite>) analysis of the 1000 most cited papers on visible nonverbal behavior, and Nadeau et al (<cite data-doi="10.7202/1045307ar">2018</cite>) analysis of the influence of various disciplines in criminology literature.

This systematic literature review acquired its data on November 15, 2021 for the period up to October 2021 from Scopus, which is the world’s largest, high-quality repository of bibliometric information for scientific articles [ <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.techfore.2021.120649"> 29 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.tre.2020.102067"> 39 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 100 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03387-8"> 101 </cite> ]. Specifically, this review employed a three-stage content filtration strategy, which includes (1) specifying relevant search terms using Boolean operators [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11356-021-13094-3"> 30 </cite> , 47 , <cite data-doi="10.1109/tem.2020.2980733"> 49 </cite> ], (2) stating the criteria for document screening [ <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.tre.2020.102067"> 39 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.cie.2021.107133"> 43 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1080/00207543.2019.1650976"> 48 </cite> ], and (3) compiling a corpus of articles based on source quality [ <cite data-doi="10.1108/ijpdlm-11-2018-0371"> 23 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.techfore.2021.120649"> 29 </cite> ] (see Table 3 ).

M. Kouhizadeh also has the greatest average number of citations, with 206.67 citations per article. In terms of author dominance reflected by the author’s dominance factor (ADF) ratio, which considers the number of times an author acts as first author in a multi-authored article and thus indicates the author’s dominant position in publishing articles [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 100 </cite> ], both T. M. Choi and B. Niu emerge as authors with the highest ADF of 1.00. Noteworthily, the number of unique top contributing authors with at least three articles between 2019 and 2021 have increased over the years, from four unique top contributing authors in 2019 to 13 and 15 unique top contributing authors in 2020 and 2021, respectively, thereby indicating that the growth of blockchain for SSCM research coincides with the growth of unique top contributing authors.

We used the Scopus database as the data source for this study. Scopus is one of the largest bibliometric database that contains the metadata necessary for a bibliometric analysis ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 12 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf"> 13 </cite> ) and combines the features of PubMed and Web of Science with a broader range of journals. Based on previous bibliometric analyses, Scopus is the appropriate data source ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03165-1"> 14 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1186/s41256-020-00165-0"> 15 </cite> ).

Although there are several sources for accessing data, the search used Scopus database because the simultaneous use of other databases might be considered unhelpful due to duplication of records (Harzing and Alakangas <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9"> 2016 </cite> ). Furthermore, Scopus is one of the largest scholarly databases of peer-reviewed literature, and at the same time it is widely accepted as a database for bibliometric and big data analysis (Mongeon and Paul-Hus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ; Donthu et al <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jbusres.2021.04.070"> 2021 </cite> ). Several authors of literature reviews have based their reviews on this database only, both in international business research (e.g., Barbieri et al <cite data-doi="10.1108/jgoss-02-2017-0004"> 2018 </cite> ; Lamba 2021 ) and other fields of business and management (e.g., Lim et al <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jbusres.2021.11.014"> 2021 </cite> ; Yadav et al <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jbusres.2022.03.005"> 2022 </cite> ).

Both Elsevier's Scopus and Clarivate Analytics' Web of Science are major sources that bibliometricians often consult. To fulfil this paper's objectives, it was more appropriate to use Scopus because of its wider publication coverage in all disciplines and wider language coverage and because it is more up to date in indexing publications on COVID-19 (Belli et al, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03590-7"> 2020 </cite> ; da Silva et al, 2020 ; Haghani & Bliemer, 2020 ; Mongeon & Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ). Furthermore, SciVal, a web-based analytics solution from Elsevier assisting those who evaluate research engagement and impact worldwide (Elsevier 2021a , 2021b ), was used as an advantageous tool accessed through Scopus to obtain on-demand tailored reports for the target region.

Due to database selection affects the value that a bibliometric indicator takes for a given unit of analysis, the validity of bibliometric analyses for research evaluation primarily lies in the databases' representativeness of the scientific activity studied <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Additionally, it turns out that Web of Science performs significantly better than Scopus in terms of the accuracy of its journal classification system <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.02.003">(Wang & Waltman, 2016)</cite> The choice of keywords also follows from a preliminary evaluation and reasoning process.

When conducting bibliometric research, it is crucial to define the search criteria correctly so that the information obtained is relevant and accurate. Due to database selection affects the value that a bibliometric indicator takes for a given unit of analysis, the validity of bibliometric analyses for research evaluation primarily lies in the databases' representativeness of the scientific activity studied (Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>).

After thorough discussions with the panel members, we added 'unethical supervision', 'unethical supervising' and 'unethical supervisor' to the initial list of keywords. Finally, we searched these terms in Scopus and Web of Science databases because these databases have been frequently used in SLRs due to the exhaustive list of journals they host, particularly in social sciences research <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>.

Figure 1 represents the literature search and selection process. Scientific literature was identified using Web of Science and Scopus, which are still considered the main sources of citation data <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>, for the period between 1998 and 2019. The literature search was conducted between September and December 2019 using the following search terms: (River* OR stream* OR channel*) and (Restoration* OR Management* OR Rehabilitation*) and (Social OR Societal OR Human) and (benefit* OR success*) and ("Ecosystem Services") screening titles and abstracts.

Scopus is a convenient, widely used, robust database and with many additional features in comparison to other databases such as Web of Science (WoS) and Google Scholar (Bosman et al , 2006 ; <cite data-doi="10.1080/00207543.2019.1605225">Thürer et al , 2020</cite>). Furthermore, a comparison of Scopus and WoS journal coverage revealed relatively small number of journals indexed exclusively in WoS (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>), and approximately 97% of WoS journals are also included in Scopus. Thus, Scopus has established a compelling reputation for conducting systematic reviews (<cite data-doi="10.1080/13683500.2018.1564739">Centobelli and Ndou, 2019</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">Vieira and Gomes, 2009</cite>).

For this purpose, we conducted a structured Boolean-type keyword search in the Scopus database (Aivazidou et al, <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jclepro.2016.07.210"> 2016 </cite> ). Although we acknowledge that both the Scopus and Web of Science databases cover the vast majority of scientific journals in the fields of business and management, natural sciences and engineering that are relevant to this study (Mongeon & Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ), we exclusively used the Scopus database for our literature search queries. We focused on Scopus because it is a widely accepted database for searching and mapping the extant literature (Fahimnia et al, <cite data-doi="10.1111/deci.12369"> 2019 </cite> ; Pournader et al, <cite data-doi="10.1080/00207543.2019.1650976"> 2020 </cite> ).

We used the Scopus database to retrieve information about research papers published by the selected institutions. Its coverage mainly focuses on research articles rather than other types of outputs, such as books, conference proceedings, or gray literature (Mongeon & Paul‐Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">2016</cite>).

Then, the keywords were combined with Booleans "AND" and "OR", with searches being carried out from April to May 2019 in the electronic databases Scopus and Web of Science (WoS), as they have a significant number of indexed relevant journals alingned to the research theme <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Scopus is considered by the academic community as the largest interdisciplinary base and, according to <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jclepro.2019.06.162">Azevedo, Scavarda, Caiado (2019)</cite> WoS helps to complement Scopus results, achieving a more complete and systematic survey.

The key search words or phrases were "Organisational capability"

The Scopus database was selected because it is considered the largest abstract and citation database of peer-reviewed academic literature in different research areas <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jrurstud.2018.11.003">(Dias, Rodrigues, & Ferreira, 2019)</cite>. Moreover, as <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite> stated, Scopus has a better coverage of journals than the Web of Science as far as management science is concerned.

We selected Scopus for this study. Scopus has a more comprehensive journal coverage and broader social science inclusion than WoS (Mongeon and Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ; Baas et al, <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00019"> 2020 </cite> ; Waltman and Larivière, <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_e_00026"> 2020 </cite> ). Also, despite being an Anglo-American/Western-oriented database, the international coverage authorship in Scopus from higher-income countries such as the US, the UK, or Germany showed a decrease since 2000, while developing regions have increased their participation significantly (e.g., China and India) (Thelwall and Sud, <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00177"> 2022 </cite> ).

The papers used in this study were gathered from Scopus, the database with the largest scientific journal coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus 2016)</cite>. In order to include most of the body of literature about the topic, the search was performed using a broad and general search field, i.e.

There are several online databases such as WoS, SCOPUS, Dimensions and Google Scholar, which researchers can use to gather data for bibliometric analysis. Nevertheless, considering the wider coverage of publications, particularly in the field of sciences (<cite data-doi="10.1177/1741143218822772">Hallinger, 2019</cite>; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>) and relatively stable search results as compared to Google Scholar, in this study, we used the SCOPUS database to search and retrieve data for our analysis.

In the meantime, types of souvenirs that drew tourists’ interest were identified: “handicraft,” “craft,” “textile,” “handcraft,” “tourist art,” and “postcard.” Therefore, search terms included: souvenir; handicraft/craft/textile/handcraft/postcard + tourism/tourist/travel; tourist + art. Web of Science (WoS) and Scopus are most frequently selected as the data source for bibliometric analysis (<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). WoS provides coverage of high-impact journals in social science, but this coverage is also a limitation.

The data collection process was conducted following the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) guidelines <cite data-doi="10.1371/journal.pmed.1000097">(Moher et al, 2009)</cite> as illustrated in Figure 1. The data collection process started with identifying relevant documents based on the topic 'Mathematics Learning from Concrete to Abstract' from the Scopus database which serves as the main database for the bibliometric analysis because of its wide interdisciplinary coverage <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. The document identification was conducted using the 'Title-Abstract-Keyword' search with four different search strings.

For the data, we used the Scopus database. However, the main scientific repositories such as Web Of Science, Scopus, PubMed, and Google Scholar have been consulted, following the recommendations of <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">Harzing and Alakangas (2016)</cite> and <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus (2016)</cite>. Scopus was selected because 1) it is the repository that contains the largest volume of information in terms of authors, countries, and institutions <cite data-doi="10.7710/2162-3309.2266">(Zhang and Eichmann-Kalwara, 2019)</cite>; 2) it contains the greatest volume of articles and journals that meet the scientific quality requirements of peer review <cite data-doi="10.5860/crl.64.6.468">(Ackerson and Chapman, 2003;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-010-0270-0">Mingers and Lipitakis, 2010)</cite>; 3) although its metrics correlate highly with Web of Science, the coverage provided by the latter is lower <cite data-doi="10.1186/1742-5581-3-7">(Bakkalbasi et al, 2006;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1002/asi.21062">Archambault et al, 2009)</cite>; and 4) it shows detailed attributes and variables of publications <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1733-0">(Nascimento and Rodrigues, 2015)</cite>.

The data used in this study come from the core collection of web of science (WoS), because the WoS database covers a wide range of outstanding journals in various academic fields, and we can find accurate author, journal, publication date, keyword and other information that can be used for analysis (Ellegaard and Wallin, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1645-z"> 2015 </cite> ; Mongeon and Paul-Hus, <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 2016 </cite> ; Ye et al, <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122679"> 2020 </cite> ) in the database. In order to ensure the authoritative and scientific nature of the article, we limit the literature type to “article”.

Despite that the Scopus scientific database is the largest database of peer-reviewed literature <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.11.064">[29]</cite>, WoS and Scopus databases have similar journal coverage within the field of Natural Sciences and Engineering, which is the main field of this study, where Scopus covers 38% and WoS 33% of journals <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[30]</cite>. Besides, the present research focuses on understanding the relation between two themes, not a comparison from databases [1].

Following the best practice <cite data-doi="10.1177/0149206309337489">[22]</cite> and procedures in other published review articles <cite data-doi="10.1007/s10551-016-3122-x">[4,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1080/00472778.2021.1955122">9,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1111/apps.12236">23,</cite><cite data-doi="10.3390/su132414009">24]</cite>, we searched the Web of Science (WOS) database and China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI) for relevant peer-reviewed articles that were published in journals with a social-science citation index, a science citation index, an engineering index, and a Chinese social-science citation index. Web of Science (WOS) was widely used in previous academic research <cite data-doi="10.1080/00472778.2021.1955122">[9,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11365-015-0356-5">[25]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.techfore.2019.119752">[26]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1177/1094428114562629">[27]</cite> and it is regarded as the most comprehensive source of articles in social science <cite data-doi="10.1080/00472778.2021.1955122">[9,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">28,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-009-2178-0">29]</cite>. CNKI, the Chinese knowledge information gateway website with complete resource types and comprehensive content [30], was used because many studies that are published in top journals in China are also highly relevant to our review topic and can add significant insights.

However, filtering studies according to time of publication and English language could lead to chronological and geographical discriminations, respectively <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[73]</cite>.

The point at which we departed from this method was the identification of publications within the Web of Science database. Recent studies have relied on this repository because it contains the most prominent journals of every discipline <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[72,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2006.12.001">73]</cite>. To retrieve publications from the Web of Science, a search vector is needed.

Their opinion was echoed by many other researchers <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.buildenv.2018.12.059">(Darko et al, 2019;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.autcon.2017.12.002">Hosseini et al, 2018b)</cite>. Also, it has been proved that in the field of construction research, Scopus has a relatively more extensive coverage than other sources, like Google Scholar and Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1061/(asce)co.1943-7862.0001492">(Hosseini et al, 2018a;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2014.07.006">van Eck & Waltman, 2014;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.autcon.2019.01.010">Yin et al, 2019)</cite>. Therefore, this study selected Scopus to collect the BIM-based coordination articles for further research.

The choice of using only Scopus or WoS may result in bias, as their coverage differs substantially <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016</cite>). As such, all possible identified keyword combinations are searched for in both Scopus and in WoS.

The data required for bibliometric analyses were gathered between mid-November and mid-December 2020 from Clarivate Analytics' Web of Science (WoS) Core Collection (SCI, SSCI, A&HCI). WoS is one of the most well-known multidisciplinary databases with a long and constant coverage of high-quality papers, which is widely used in bibliometric analysis <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. In this study, different search strategies have been defined for each one of the TIAs (more information on the strategies used in Table S.1).

On November 1 st , 2021, the dental caries literature was screened via Elsevier's Scopus as it provides the largest abstract and citation database of peer-reviewed scientific literature <cite data-doi="10.1096/fj.07-9492lsf">(Falagas et al, 2008;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1001/jama.2009.1307">Kulkarni et al, 2009;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2015;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1177/0022034519880544">Ahmad et al, 2019)</cite>. The first step was to define search words that would be used to screen the literature; search words included dental caries terms (n=12) and omics-related terms (n=44).

Quality databases with accurate and consistent information are essential <cite data-doi="10.1533/9781780630182">[76,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.iedeen.2016.02.001">77]</cite>. Therefore, the Scopus database was selected for the search, as it is considered one of the central databases with great coverage, facilitating the study and comparison of different scientific fields <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[78]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2016.02.003">[79]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00019">[80]</cite><cite data-doi="10.3390/ijerph15122727">[81]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-018-2820-9">[82]</cite><cite data-doi="10.3390/su13116039">[83]</cite>. In addition to its comprehensive coverage and ease in the tools provided for bibliometric analysis, in this specific study (artisanal and small-scale mining), we considered the main reason for the extensive coverage of Scopus in terms of scientific production related to geosciences <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.tmp.2015.03.005">[84]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.resourpol.2022.102650">[85]</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.resourpol.2021.102272">[86]</cite>.

Scopus constitutes an indexed and well-organised database of scientific production, with tools that allow the export of metadata <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2010.10.002">[63,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00019">80,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03690-4">87]</cite>. In addition, it provides a series of data on scientific publications such as authors, institutions, countries, number of citations, and research areas <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">[78,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00019">80,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1016/j.tele.2017.10.010">88,</cite><cite data-doi="10.3390/info11020069">89]</cite>. An important aspect to consider in selecting the database is that the growth in the coverage of journals from Latin America and the Caribbean indexed within the Scopus database <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-013-1036-2">[90,</cite><cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z">91]</cite> strengthens the analysis carried out in different areas.

In addition to authors and journals names, the Web of Science database indexes other metadata, including years of publications, keywords, and institutions of authors, as well as different indicators of research impact. Web of Science was chosen for this article because of the quality of its metadata compared to Google Scholar, and of the historical depth of its indexing compared to Scopus <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016;</cite>Sugimoto & Larivière, 2018).

The bias can be minimised by seeking the opinions of experts to identify the appropriate level of visualisation and having a high-level agreement in the interpretation of results, <cite data-doi="10.1007/978-3-319-10377-8_13"> 23 </cite> both of which were used in our study. Despite the strengths of Web of Science, there are limitations including the database being orientated to articles published in English <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 31 </cite> and a mismatch between the articles and journals indexed by the databases used in this study (5,578 articles indexed in PEDro (12.7%) could not be matched to Web of Science and were excluded from the analyses). Also, PEDro excludes qualitative, observational and other research designs so this study only reflects the status of research in physical therapy interventions.

This article was searched on 17 April 2022 through the Science Citation Index Expanded (SCIE) and Social Sciences Citation Index (SSCI) databases in the Web of Science Core Collection for articles on natural biopolymers from the 21st century. The reason why the WOSCC database was selected for retrieval is that compared with other databases (PubMed and Scopus), it contains more than 10,000 subject areas such as environment, medical care, ecology, and agriculture, with international authority, great influence, high quality, and long history of research data ( <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9"> Harzing and Alakangas, 2016 </cite> ; <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016 </cite> ; <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.autcon.2017.04.002"> Zhao, 2017 </cite> ). In order to avoid bias due to the daily update of the WOSCC database, the articles required for the search were carried out within one day on 17 April 2022, and articles published from 1 January 2022, were excluded because, from this period, any collection from that year will include incomplete bibliometric data for that year.

Mongeon and Paul-H [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 36 </cite> ] compared the coverage of active scholarly journals in WoS (13,605 journals) and Scopus (20,346 journals) with Ulrich’s extensive periodical directory (63,013 journals) stipulating that the use of either WoS or Scopus may introduce biases that favor Natural Sciences and Engineering as well as Biomedical Research to the detriment of Social Sciences and Arts and Humanities and English-language journals are overrepresented to the detriment of other languages. The results of Vera-Baceta et al [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z"> 38 </cite> ] supported the same conclusion.

The results of Vera-Baceta et al [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-019-03264-z"> 38 </cite> ] supported the same conclusion. Mongeon and Paul-Hus [ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 36 </cite> ] highlighted that the coverage of both databases differs substantially.

Most bibliometric studies use two databases as their primary sources of information: Elsevier’s Scopus and Thomson Reuters’ Web of Science (WoS). There are various studies providing arguments in analysing the journal coverage of those two databases in terms of field, publishing country and language ([ <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5"> 36 </cite> , <cite data-doi="10.1016/j.joi.2008.08.001"> 37 </cite> ]).

<cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-020-03387-8">41</cite> Based on the interdisciplinary coverage on journals, and data quality, the use of these two for research evaluation may introduce biases that favor Natural Sciences and Engineering as well as biomedical research. <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">42</cite> Harzing, A.-W. and S. Alakangas (2016) also showed that the three data bases: Web of Science, Scopus and Google Scholar are consistent and stable in coverage for both citations and publications for multidiscipline including Engineering and science. <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1798-9">43</cite> Another database resource used by researcher looking literature in biological science is PubMed, which is the largest number one and most well-organized, <cite data-doi="10.3346/jkms.2013.28.9.1270">44</cite> and accessed for free.

These include low instances of author duplication, organisation of authors by discipline, more accurate metrics and the availability of authors' institutional affiliation histories. Additionally, the coverage of journals in Scopus is broader than that of Web of Science <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2015)</cite> and it has more extensive coverage of psychology than PsycINFO (García-Pérez, 2010). Furthermore, the Scopus advanced search tools allowed us to limit each academic's publication and citation records to those prior to 1 January 2020.

These four methods are qualitative, common and relatively straightforward to identify by keyword queries. Scopus was chosen as the database because it has wider coverage than the Web of Science, and particularly for non-English articles <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon & Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Thus, Scopus may capture a larger share of qualitative research if it is frequently published in national journals <cite data-doi="10.1080/13645570902966056">(Alasuutari, 2010)</cite>.

Data were extracted through the Scopus database. This database provides extensive coverage of the broad variety of scientific journals that exist in the field <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. It has, therefore, been used in the literature as a source of bibliometric data for a large-scale analysis of research evaluations and research landscape studies <cite data-doi="10.1162/qss_a_00019">(Baas et al, 2020;</cite><cite data-doi="10.1080/00207543.2019.1671625">Kipper et al, 2020;</cite><cite data-doi="10.3390/su13137304">Gao et al, 2021;</cite><cite data-doi="10.18178/ijiet.2021.11.9.1541">Sobral, 2021)</cite>.

Another important element in the critical analysis of the data obtained is the origin of the selected publications. The four main countries producing the selected literature are four English-speaking countries, in line with the data provided by some studies that warn of the over-representation of English-language journals to the detriment of other languages <cite data-doi="10.1007/s11192-015-1765-5">(Mongeon and Paul-Hus, 2016)</cite>. Once again, English-speaking researchers are privileged over other contexts.
